lYe3heyEcn0Nj51TyShmTg.review_text: Wow This place is amazing. A secret little Japanese restaurant tucked into a corner of japantown behind a very hard to find door. The Best japanese dining experience I've ever had! My wife and I tried the omikaze. (whatever the chef has in mind for you. ) and wow what an amazing mouthwatering experience. Make reservations because this place is only open for 4 hours a night and only sits about 12. A very very special experience! Thank you Kappa , we will be back

fVjdQVRWNZ0MljH8UWzayA.review_text: finding this place is 1/2 the fun. I heard about it from my friend "above the Denny's in Japantown."  you go above the denny's and you see a karaoke place and a small sign next to closed wooden door. If you read Chinese, it says "small eats" (or so tells me my friend) if you read hiragana the sign says "kappa"  so, we knocked on the door. We asked if they were open b/c of the closed door. The waitress said yes "but we don't serve sushi."  I thought to myself good b/c I don't do raw. When we said can we come in. The waitress again said we don't serve sushi. i said fine. Then she brought the menu to make sure we were ok.  It is high-end japanese tapas or food to go with drinking. they serve sashimi but not sushi.  divine fatty pork, divine everything. very pricey. very small, only seats like 7 at the bar, and 1 room of 4 people...  reserve in advance or risk being turned away. or perhaps just try dropping in...  there is just the chef and the waitress. perfect service.

vASaF47nWvCHEEDA8nfCVw.review_text: There's something elegant yet understated about this restaurant, tucked away in an unassuming location within Japantown.  The lack of sign and the unmarked sliding door, which leads to a dining room capable of fitting no more than 12 guests at any given time, would surely keep the tourists (or those who are not in the know) away.  The establishment consists of a private room with a small table for 3 and a small sushi bar with 9 little chairs and almost no decor.   Everything else in the entire Kappa experience is just like the restaurant itself - the minimalist menu is devoid of glossy colorful pictures (and, sometimes, English translation), each dish (no sushi!) is beautifully presented sans fancy garnishment, and service is excellent yet not overbearing.    Intimate and personable, this must've been what it feels like to stop by an old aunt (whose culinary skill is out of this world)'s house for a homemade dinner.    Without the annoying inquisitive aunt hovering about in the background, of course.

mE-hdFF4RgCxspZU72GAsw.review_text: Not sure how to start this review, so I'll leave it up to you; here are 3 options:  1.) Saved about $1400 on two tickets to Japan last night! Instead, I walked there!  2.) This is why we live in SF, why we deal with the outrageous costs and the damn parking tickets. It's because of places like this!  3.) Someone once told me, the first thing you should eat in a Japanese restaurant is the tamago, and the quality of the tamago would dictate the rest of the evening. The Japanese  group next to me did just that. In fact, the chef had a big block of tomago on the counter that looked and tasted outstanding. Judging by the look on their (and our) faces, it was going to be a great evening.  Now here's the rest: We were the only 'foreigners' in the place. Everyone else spoke Japanese. And we were the only ones doing the Omokase. Although I can't afford this place on a weekly basis, I feel blessed we were able to experience it. Next time, I'm ordering off the menu. But, if it's your first time, I don't suggest you do the same. Get the omokase. Enjoy. (and the flight home won't be bumpy (or long.))

Rt2BtV0Xbwrd_h9KoCXtvw.review_text: We had the $85 omakase.  It was good -- but not fabulous.  The toro, katsu, duck breast, and ankimo were all very good.  The rest of the meal (asparagus over some sauce, red bean dessert, etc.) was just OK, though.  Much of the meal obviously had been prepared well in advance, and the chef was just slicing everything and laying it out in front of us.  While the others in my party were full, I left a bit hungry.    Good, attentive (but not annoying so) service.  Good sake selection/recommendations.    All totaled, $120 a person.  Only 3* because, for the cost, I don't think I would rush back here.

njNP6Gw1MfPWVqQKhs3Dsw.review_text: I give two stars for the awesome food, but for atmosphere they put us in the tight corner, where you hardly had room to move around and that young with that streaks of blond in hair must be having a bad day,. Her service sucks...otherwise the food is delicious...

2-ZpF_iIHgc_5njdiJfM3A.review_text: My wife and I had omakase.  For the most part it was very delicious.  The dashi broth dumpling and salad were very good.  The smoked salmon... not so much.  Everything else was very good.  Service was impeccable.  The chef and his wife were very hospitable.  I would say they can even cut down on some of the portion sizes in a few of his dishes because the sizes of some of his cuts were a bit too big.  Overall, I would highly recommend it to anyone.  Do not order sushi because they don't have it on their menu.

3roJp-RoqKVoMgdtuJFM9Q.review_text: *chirp*chirp* the silence deepens  we were running a few minutes behind and called to let them know, and they said it was alright. i knew the place was somewhere next to milo, and sworn i had seen it before. luckily once you walk up the stairs...the door was open and viola! it says Kappa..and then  you see a wooden slide door...and I'm like hmm is it in here...and you slide it and into a zen Japanese place.  We were the only ones there at 6pm, and yes, lets just say it. it was AWKWARD! felt like we had to whisper, and although they were nice, just staring at us every second didn't make me that comfortable =/  we did the omakase, and had her suggest us a sake, i preferred something sweet and she got us just that. not too sweet but perfect.  new years soup- very refreshing, light, the mochi was chewy, mushroom was tasty crab in vinegar- perfect balance tuna in a wasabi miso sauce with wakame and scallions- the sauce was a good balance b/c the wasabi was just spicy enough to hit your nose but not too overwhelming. although my bf said thats how mustard is suppose to be but i don't really know. the platter of everything- tamago (more egg-y than sweet), fish cake (yum i love fish cake in general), duck breast, salmon, conch shell? (chewy, never had it before),  asparagus in sesame paste, shrimp, corn fritter, eggplant, tonkatsu, and one more fish, and new years beans as they said. all very delightful, one easy bite, full of flavor! the sashimi...hamachi, tuna, amber jack and halibut? was so buttery and the texture was really nice. except i think i wasn't fond of amberjack...too crunchy? chewy? yea... nigiri!!  i usually dont like raw scallops but this lil guy was yummy! and right off the shell. seared toro? im guessing from pics on yelp, but it tasted like a salmon lox? the unagiiiii, my bf's chef said it would and should melt in your mouth. it totally did. every bite was savored. DROOL then the dessert- mochi, persimmon ( i like persimmons), pear, and persimmon jello, apple sauce texture. then a strawberry, raspberry, and peach sorbet.   overall definitely an experience, if you have the money to spend. it did get less awkward as the courses trickled in and another couple joined us. the wife was very hospitable and I wish I could have used my japanese language skills on her. lol   were we full? content but not stuffed which is how it should be. we did try to take our time eating..lol since we didn't want to look like fat pigs and gobble everything up. ponder and think about the flavors, yes look smart, yes  now we're excited to try other omakases! for special occasions of course. oh and my bf got a small gift b/c it was his bday. arigatou!

ifrL9DZ30ibOWX5KfXxFDA.review_text: Go here for a real indulgent treat especially around the holidays for a special menu! You won't be disappointed! Great service as well.

dm2zyOFEl2ZMMRGUYjc-Zw.review_text: Walking thru the door of kappa (assuming you can did it..) it's like crossing a portal to japan. Everything here, the decoration, the hominess, the wife-husband duo, and all the dishes is close to perfection. I'm sure the chief is keenly working towards it. Just like jiro always is.

v-6rnKSlJC9rE0mi1AiPyg.review_text: Best Japanese meal I've had. This place has been in business for 25 years. It seats 10. Had the omakasse. Run by a husband and wife team. Entrance is hidden away next to a karaoke bar. What else do you need to know? Dinner and two sake was $150 with tip.

eRkLCltnCb5EYcK0928t-Q.review_text: Wow, Kappa was a disappointment. For a 4.5 star rated restaurant, I was expecting a lot more.  We ordered the omakase for $85 each. Overall it was a big let down.   Started with 2 sashimi size pieces of soy sauce/shiso marinated marinated tuna with scallions. Ok, tasted fine, but hardly unique. I can get that at any sushi bar.  Next was an interesting bowl of fish gelatin, fish eggs, fish, and okra. It was ok.  Then we had a plate of sashimi and other bite size foods. BBQ unagi, sardine nigiri, duck breast. I think there was nine pieces of stuff. Not that tasty, nor original, except for the single slice of duck breast.  Next was a bowl with 6 pieces of sashimi. 2 tuna, 1 yellowtail, 1 halibut, 1 mackeral, and some uni. Didn't taste fresh, and I hate mackeral.  Then a small plate with a shrimp ball, corn fritter, and grilled miso-marinated seabass. I felt like I could have gotten the shrimp ball from a street vendor for $1. The corn fritter was very salty. The seabass was a charred mess. I sent it back.   Finally we had a soup dish with an egg custard square, some fresh fruit, and green tea ice crea.  In total, with tax , tip, and hot tea we were over $200.  Aside from the food, which was nothing special, the chef would prepare everyone's (as in, everyone in the restaurant) dishes at the same time. Therefore, if you weren't the first group finished with your plate, your next plate would be preplated and waiting next to the dirty dishes in the sink, cold, or over-cooked.  If you really want an authentic japanese restaurant like this, then go to Kiss. If you're looking for fresh fish on rice, go to your favorite sushi place and you'll leave much happier.

DW48cVl8pVGEC787UPfVtA.review_text: There is not much to say that other reviewers have not said about this place. Somehow I neglected to review it after our trip to SF a few weeks back, so here it is, to the best of my recollection.   We made reservations a few days in advance, shortly after touching down. I did not want to miss a chance to dine here. Luckily we got to Japantown about 25 minutes prior to the reservation, as it was very hidden. It's up a flight of stairs next to a bar. Small letters on the door say KAPPA.  We did the omakase, as suggested, and it did not disappoint. If I recall, there was sashimi,  a cold cucumber salad, a shrimp, some dumplings, a red bean desert, and a melon-y ice cream, just to name some of the items. All delicious, all different, all elegantly presented. It was quiet. There were 2 other couples dining when we were there at the counter area where you sit. A table in the back which accommodated about 4-5 people. And that's it. Looks like it holds about 10-12 people at a time, max. Very friendly couple running the place. It was more than eating. It was definitely an experience.

8hvXl0oJmU61l17LG9aDag.review_text: conversation with a life long friend.  friend : hey lets go out to dinner. i found out about this place thats supposed to be real high end japo food. its on top of dennys in jtown.  me : on top of dennys? are you talking about the korean bar? theres a restaurant on top of dennys? you smoke too much weed man. i think you are mixing up info.   when we arrived, we were like wtf, where the hell is this place. called, a lady said she will come right out. a completely non descriptive door opens and whoa... theres a restaurant there?  the place itself is tiny... seriously about the size of my old room in my sisters mcmansion in fremont. (yeah, shes the successful one, im the kid in the parents basement one). since we were a large party for the place, 3 people!!!, they stuck us in a little room away from the counter. i was so lost. ive been around japanese food all my life, but pseudo japanese (big ups to nobu). kappa is the real deal japanese cuisine. i didnt know up from down here.  glancing over the menu, everyone had the look.  me : mmmmmm i dont know. i took japanese for two years but other than _______ ku dae sai, i dont know shit.... thank you public school education.  we went with the omakase..... like ive said many times, who knows their best dishes better than the staff?   mmmmmm basically, i LOVED everything. i really couldnt tell you what i had, what it was, but i can tell you what it wasnt.... it wasnt a rainbow catapillar sunshine out my ass roll with tonkastu sauce. every small dish came out and was greeted by us with oooo and ahhhhs... the simple elegant balance of each dish was wonderful. the gracious lady matched up some cold sake for us also. excellent.  for so many courses, we didnt get stuffed. more like a very pleasant full.   it felt like a mini vacation to japan. a very good experience. now would i frequent it often? probably not. though the food is VERY VERY good, i prefer a more lowbrow dining experience. im a lowly salary man so stick me in an izakaya.. KAMPAI!

BCHyzFtX1R5eZ5AoOkuONQ.review_text: Kappa was a must experience. The bar only fits 8 people. The restaurant is ran by a Japanese couple. The waitress/owner was beauitful and very lady like, and her husband focused on cooking. There is a room that you could book for a small party.   This hidden gem is inside/next to Milo Lounge. I couldn't find it and had to call my friend for directions since I didn't want to call the restaurant. Once you walk through the door, you are in a whole different universe. It was dead quiet, and you truly focus on the food.   Beautiful presentations and fresh seafood. My first omakase experience!

cfVDBmjnlY2iJaBqz7D2Ng.review_text: Had the omakase. Probably the best meal of my life. The eel.. was amazing. The husband and wife who own the place are really nice. I came here for my birthday, and the wife gave me a birthday present before I left!

fK9p4IrqIpdJY4EbYPQSfQ.review_text: One should know that what truly differentiates Kappa from the rest of Bay Area Japanese restaurants is their veggie dishes.  I have never had such authentic Japanese vegetables perfectly prepared in such an authentic way at any of Japanese restaurants around here.   Where do they get their vegetables?  I'm dying to find out.  They don't just cross over the street to Nijiya, for sure.

ylRKufHFoOIs1_B4VLIJkQ.review_text: We both had a very nice meal. This is a small Japanese Restaurant that is operated by a very nice husband and wife team. They have been perfecting their business for the past 25 years and it shows how much passion they exhibit. The Chefs menu had many fresh ingredients from Japan which resulted in a well executed and Delicious meal. We are looking forward to returning soon.

ut9LXMr6uLDoATXHQExgIg.review_text: Making our way from the chaos of the Japantown Mall to Kappa, we were transported to an all together different dimension of being. The term 'Tappas' has been overused, so I'll use the less oft used 'small plates' to describe the Koriyori cuisine at this small/micro establishment. The prix fixe menu apparently changes from day to day, so I'm not sure what I might be served on my return visit (and I will return), but the dishes wrought surprised ahhh's from my lips time and again on this occasion. A bite of sea essence contained within perfectly creamy uni, followed by seared duck? Yes, more please! After having just enjoyed Joss Whedon's Much Ado About Nothing, all I could think was 'get thee to Kappa...get thee to Kappa!' But, be certain to make reservations and prepare for a leisurely, drawn out meal.

nwKsR5_epCypSzGPsMn0HA.review_text: It is definitely a hidden restaurant in Japantown.  Looking for this restaurant for the first time was challenging.  It was upstairs of the J-town Denny's, next to Playground (Korean karaoke lounge).    The restaurant is very tiny and traditional.  It made you feel like you are dining in the traditional Japanese home.  The waitress (the chief's wife) was so sweet and friendly.  There is no standard menu here. Instead, you will be treated to unique meals based upon only the freshest ingredients available during the time.  We wanted to have Omakase, but they required one day in advance for reservation......TOO BAD!  We started off the Sashimi Combo.  The fish was good and fresh but it was not the best.    Since we have no idea of what to order, so we asked the waitress to order couple dishes for us.  My favor of the night was the Dungeness crab meat, and pickled cucumber with sesame seeds.  Very refreshing!  Overall, the food is simple here but it presented in a unique way which is hard to find in other Japanese restaurants.  However, this place is super expensive and I would have higher expectations.   The food is good but just but not to die for and memorable.

Vf3DJncooLUHWYele0Cxrw.review_text: Impossible to find tiny tiny little place to get Omakase.  The whole experience here is well to be had, but I doubt the place sees many regulars.

rqMYol4ZfvLm9WmIMtV4IA.review_text: 7 course omakase for $95 is overrated.   As much as I was hoping to come home and rave about this place, I just can't seem to figure out how other fellow Yelpers can give this place 5 golden stars. My experience here was well, underwhelming and unsatisfying. I didn't just pay $95 for some fried chicken, fried corn and egg plant... which was surprisingly part of our third course. Nor did I expect to have half a strawberry, orange and sorbet as my seventh course as dessert. (C'mon, for a $95 meal you think you'd at least have something better than that!) I have paid $200 for a twenty course omakase before and it was the real sh*t! I'm talking about sashimi and other seafood in every course! Other than the soup that was served as the first course, none of the other dishes here stood out to me. I was pleased to finally see sashimi served as our fourth course; however the quality of the fish was mediocre.  I definitely don't see myself coming back here, not anytime soon at least.

YdRlFZAkjUEhmO1KT7oKtg.review_text: i kinda feel like i shouldn't write about kappa because its so special and i want to keep it that way.... incredible japanese food, owned by an adorable japanese couple. get the set menu (although i think you have to) - they make you a special dinner, 7 courses or something crazy like that - stuff like seamed sea urchin... soooooooooooooo good and special and wonderful. i'm pretty sure you have to make a reservation because they buy just enough to feed their guests for the night!

Fs2NdgpjX0AIA5dVrr48Eg.review_text: I can only say this place is bizarre. I went there saturday night with my girlfriend and there was only one other couple in the restaurant. The food was generally pretty good, some things very good, but some things very poor like the chicken which was of very low quality.   Also, for the price, there is absolutely no way this place competes with the best SF restaurants. Friendly service, but the place was dead calm, no music, no one else talking, just a weird dining experience that was very expensive. One waitress and one cook upstairs from where denny's used to be in japan town. I cannot explain all the very positive reviews, and frankly I am at a loss. I have a hard time believing these reviews are real, but whatever, good luck if you go here.

BQr4xLs0IpO3MBjPe1ns2w.review_text: Omakase. Kubota and Hakkaisan sake. A wonderful experience that almost lead me to tears. Tears of joy. If you appreciate Japanese food, you will not be disappointed during and after dining here. I dare say its a oral orgasam. Sit at the bar so you can watch the chef owner put your artistic dinner on to the plates. Will return soon.

OUg8qQgRikF-ySoFzuqUzQ.review_text: this small little joint has a very authentic feel to it. i could have been convinced that i was in Kyoto again. When i was there, there were only two people working: the chef and the Okami-san, and i had a very nice extended chat with the latter (i'm not sure because i didn't try relying solely on English, but i get the feeling that knowing Japanese is very helpful here). There are drawbacks, however. Vegetarian options are limited, and i left $30 poorer and still hungry.

CYvwH-v8pvaR3K3e4jtbrQ.review_text: The location and sliding door are just as the other yelp reviewers have said, hidden, very Japanese and very cute. We sat in the small private room at the small tetragon shaped table and had the omakase. The service was great with the wife in a lovely kimono and very hospitable. Each course came out super quick and nicely presented. The dinnerware was beautiful from crystal to blown glass bowls to traditional Japanese ceramics. The food was well executed but to be honest, it didn't completely blow me away. However, I'm not so in to challenging foods. I'm pretty moderate in my taste buds so some of the flavors pushed my limits although I tried a bite of everything. The wasabi is freshly grated and the tea is matcha. I found the meal generous and I was very full by the end but my husband and I tend toward a small appetite so it may feel light for some folks.

0DqHs2Fyak-6COeZRJEE7Q.review_text: I've worked in restaurants. I work in customer service. I know that sometimes things happen and you get backed up and it's hard to catch up, so I'm generally pretty understanding of less than spectacular service, but every once in a while...  Our party dropped in to Kappa for a much deserved feast after a long day of park exploration. We let our server know how we would be splitting our check upon ordering in an attempt to alleviate any confusion. It was fairly busy when we got there, and slowly cleared as the the other guests finished their meals. The staff were running around in chaos. They only had one chef that day, and you could tell it was getting to them.   None of our orders came out together,  but it did get to us eventually and when we finally got our food, it was super bomb. The sushi chef made us a special roll, on the house, which was redeeming.  Even with our orders on separate tickets, it took our server 20 minutes to get us our bills (no really, we went out for a cigarette and then still waited) and a couple of the checks were incorrect.  Kudos to the Kappa chefs, the food was incredible. They just seem to need a little more organization up front.

65uXk38DABB4uofHRP7VyQ.review_text: 4.5 stars for the food, rounded up to 5 stars for the ambiance and impeccable service. As other's have mentioned, its location is somewhat hidden. For those who remember Denny's in J-Town, this restaurant is located on the top floor of the same building. Denny's is no longer there, but there is signage for Playground Karaoke in the same building; Kappa is located right next door to Playground Karaoke, with old signage on the door for a club that used to be there. I was in love with this place the moment I stepped through the door. I felt like I was beamed to a small restaurant in Japan, far far away from San Francisco.  The main area has 10 bar seats; the restaurant also offers a private room that seats 4.  The Mrs. is super friendly (w/o being intrusive) and made us feel right at home.   It was our first time at the restaurant so we opted for the omakase (which has to be ordered at min. one day in advance). Kappa's omakase is a 7-course meal (including dessert) and a fair amount of food. Ingredients used on all the dishes were fresh and the Chef Kimura's skills are solid. Unlike kaiseki cuisine that sports complex flavors and more intricate presentations, Kappa offers koryori cuisine where flavors were simple, elegant, and pleasant. These were dishes in our omakase tonight, from upper left to lower right in photo: yelp.com/biz_photos/jI7h… 1) Sake (ordered separately) 2) Tempura fish with lemon juice squeezed on the top, dipped in some fancy sea salt - loved this dish! 3) Crab in vinegar w/cucumber and sesame 4) Asparagus in sesame dressing 5) The main course with 13 items! Fried taro with dark miso, fried fish cake, squid + spicy code roe roll, duck (very flavorful!), egg yolk roll (with seafood on top), ankimo (monk fish liver), shrimp, tofu-mochi (very interesting in a good way), scallops, meatball, anago roll, yuzu radish (super refreshing), and baby octopus (probably my favorite on this plate) 6) Sashimi course: tuna, hamachi, smoked salmon, and halibut w/fresh wasabi 7) Grilled hamachi sushi, unagi sushi, and fried corn 8) Mango mousse 9) Left: Sakura mochi (one of the BEST mochi I have ever had!). Right: Mochi with red bean filling and soy bean powder on the outside The damage came out to be around the same as Wakuriya in San Mateo so depending on whether you prefer kaiseki or koryori cuisine, you may want to splurge at one or the other. A meal at Wakuriya is generally slower-paced and takes 2-3 hours, whereas our meal at Kappa tonight took ~1.5 hours.  We came on the Monday evening after Mother's Day (probably extra quiet at most restaurants!) and there was only one other couple at the restaurant so it may be a little easier to get a reservation here at Kappa than Wakuriya (which also has limited seating). We'll be back!

6m54nq7IilsWW2wXEd4Vkg.review_text: What a great experience to dine here when we made a last minute reservation on the night that the Cherry Blossom Festival was in force. We did not realize that the event was going on and parking was a big issue.   However, we found parking blocks away and were late for the reservation, but somehow it all worked out as our seats were not given out to other patrons.  They are open from 6-9 p.m. and reservations are accepted after 4:30 p.m.  I would love to go back but I do not want to be served the same omakase that I saw on yelp that we were served that evening. I would hope that they would serve a seasonal omakase, so we'll wait 6 months to venture to this place again.

a27Uotn3zg8r2hLi-ckzwA.review_text: A wonderful dining experience. The husband and wife team (Toshiaki & Rumiko Kimura) are very gracious and attentive to detail. The food is prepared very simply, highlighting the freshness and depth of taste and flavors. My partner and I went for a special occasion dinner, and as such, we indulged in the Koryori style Pre-Fixed menu (starts at $85 per person and requires one day advance notice). We felt like we were transported back to Japan and some of the great little local restaurants we had eaten at. In completing our total surrender, we allowed the owner to match the food with several appropriate sakes throughout the meal service.  Ambiance is quiet and calm...you know, Zen like feel. They must be doing something right since they have been in business for almost 25 years now.  Well worth the price.

pl5IeWLa9jPcwaABaUk4rA.review_text: I enjoyed a nice intimate dinner here a couple weeks back.  I wanted to try something unique and I'm glad I shared in this 8-course Omakase style experience.   My bill came to about $260 for two dinners and an order of sake.  The food was delicious with much of it delicate playful seafood plates.  There's a very attentive couple who run this small establishment with a cute sliding door entrance into a private sushi bar suite.  It's very simple and straight forward inside, but I very much felt like I was "somewhere else" trying something different amongst a few other special guests.  I would recommend this place for couples on special occasions.

ilesK4CRarjiblkxUDL_tQ.review_text: My mother-in-law and her husband are visiting us from Canada so we decided to treat her at one of SF's best Japanese restaurant.   Not the typical Japanese restaurant nor the typical Omakase.   The location was a bit hard to find but we end up finding it after going up and down on Post street.  We just came back from eating at Kappa. Starved, we ordered the Omakase and got served right away.  The dishes were very flavourful and tasty. Loved the fact that the chef took the time to introduce us to the various types of Japanese food (fried, raw, poached, grilled...etc). It was quite impressive.   The service was excellent. We enjoyed every bite of our Omakase. Personally, I don't think that the dishes they served us were for me (don't take me wrong, I loved the restaurant) but a lot of the dishes the chef served us were deep fried and kind of on the salty side.   After our last dish and before our first dessert, my husband and I asked for some uni. IT WAS DELICIOUS. The uni was sooooo fresh and the portion was very generous!

5IX9FOesKrLRyz618xc6tw.review_text: i've had kappa bookmarked forever and tonite we decided to go there on a whim. unfortunately (or maybe fortunately) the omakase menu requires at least 1-day notice so that the chef has enough time to prepare the dishes so we were left with ony a selection of the "koryori" menu which means traditional Japanese dishes. we ordered the hamachi and maguro sashimi ($25 for 5 generous quality pieces but still overpriced), hirame usuzukuri (thinly sliced halibut presented sashimi style with fresh green onions, spicy radish and ponzu sauce), fresh sardine from Japan simmered in a sweet brown broth, chicken tsukune (3 skewers of savory chicken meatballs), simmered green vegetables with slices of kitsune tofu, and grilled fish (sardine again).  everything tasted wonderful and the dishes were made with perfection but our favorites were the simmered sardine, hirame usuzukuri, and simmered green vegetables!   this is now my favorite japanese place in the city. thanks to the wonderful hostess (chef's wife?) for educating us on how to make authentic japanese broth from boniko and her pleasant demeanor. we will be back for sure!!!

AubdZjrTVXkyN8uPoUw87A.review_text: Very Authentic Japanese restaurant.  It was very refreshing experience since I am getting sick of Assn-Fusion and "creative" sushi these days.  I liked their simple and traditional dishes.  They also had great dry sake list (5 stars) including Otokoyama, Hakkaisan, Kikusui, and Kubota etc...   Over all 4.5 stars - I liked everything I tried: 1. Hirame Usuzukuri (thinly sliced sashimi) $25 - very fresh and great quality -5 stars 2. aFnYKllcqto1p_ZnxOT31w.review_text: Boring, uninspired food and stingy substitutions.  I had the omakase menu like everyone else and was assured that they would substitute some things on the menu, as I told them I was allergic to crab and lobster.  But when the dishes came out, it turned out that three dishes had been substitued with daikon!  So while my dinner mates feasted on crab and lobster, I just had pickled daikon.  They didn't give me any additional dishes or a discount off the omakase price, either.  The rest of the food was also not very memorable, and certain not worth the price.

sXKmP90GCdF0oM0AzYRhaQ.review_text: Sure, the place was tucked in a small dark corner of a place, and there wasn't any sign of restaurant around it, just a shut-tight dark sliding door, but there is a small sticker that says "KAPPA", which helps a little. Otherwise, the dishes crafted by the lovely husband and wife inside was worth to go hunting for! As you go up the stairs on the corner of Post and Buchanan, you'll find 2 doors. The left side has a neon sign that says "Playground". The left is an open glass door with "Milo Lounge" sign. Walk past the Milo door and standing right in front of you is Kappa's shut-tight door. Slide the door and you'll enter Japan.  When I said Japan, it really feels like you're not in San Francisco anymore. They specialized in Omakase, in which you're served a 7-course meal that includes very small, delicately prepared dishes. Each ingredient is carefully selected, making sure that they use the best graded ones in the market. Having to experience omakase for the very first time, it turned out to be an exquisite dinner. There was always an "Mmmmm" moment in every dish served.  So the 7 course breaks down to:  1. Clear soup with a snap pea, and halibut wrapped uni and a slice of yuzu peel. So subtle and delicate, it opens up your appetite and gets you ready for the following courses.  2. Goma-ae. Spinach and wakame smothered with a sesame-mustard paste, and paired it up with a piece of seared maguro block. This is intense, as the sweetness of the mustard and sesame rushed in, then calms back down as you savor the maguro.  3. Sunomono. A vibrant cucumber salad, so fresh and mouthwatering. Pairs it up with a chunk of king crab meat. (could be a dungeness or blue)  4. A fun combination platter that has 12 different things: -Boiled prawn -Unagi jello -Yolk sushi (so creative and yet so yum!) -Tonkatsu -Yakitori -Sweet corn fritter -Hamachi with ginger and soysauce -Adzuki konyaku -Asparagus with sesame paste -Herring roe -Duck breast with red miso -Grilled smoked salmon  5. Sashimi Moriawase (we were served the freshest uni, hamachi, maguro and halibut)  6.  A plate of Unagi (perhaps the BEST unagi ever!), baby scallop in its shell.  7. DESSERTS! There was icecream and home made adzuki mochi (wife made these), red bean jello, a slice of grapefruit and a slice of pear.  Everything goes well with sake! omg. I will totally come back!

epeDgCUc6WZm38bOMXIh1g.review_text: Great, great, great experience for me and Mo. The atmosphere is a little intimidating at first because of the smallness of the space. Also can be hard to find if you aren't careful and prepare beforehand. So be sure to leave enough time before you reservation to find the place.  Decor: Clean, very classic japanese, small, very intimate 10 seats MAX (thus reservations are a must-do).  Service: Very Japanese, hot fresh towel before and after meal. Wife and husband duo have clearing been doing this a long time and work very well together. Every part of your meal with be timed almost perfectly. No need to worry about anything while here.  Pricing is steep but for us was worth the splurge for the omakase experience.  As for food...Mo and I thoroughly enjoyed our experience. I have tried many things but I still was able to experience something new here at Kappa and maybe even a little out of my comfort zone. Something to be prepared for is that is NOT your typical run of the mill Japanese restaurant. Almost everything if not everything is prepared and produced by the owners. Thus the price. The style of cooking is very homey and all of the preparations are classic Japanese. If anything you are getting Japanese cuisine in its purest form. No fuss. No fancy foams or heaping plates full of food. SIMPLICITY is the theme and the key here. Food at its purest form with as little done or added to it as possible so that you are actually tasting the ingredients. If your not down for that Kappa is NOT the place for you. Mo and I went in knowing that and we had a lovely meal.

d1iQ6JAdwg3meF9WOND3og.review_text: Kappa is a quiet little Japanese restaurant with excellent food.  There's a 10 stool bar and a little corner that can fit a party of about 4.  The décor is nothing extravagant or overly fancy.  Don't get me wrong, it's still exceptionally charming and quaint.   The service is EXCELLENT!  There was always a constant flow of attention to every group.  You're never left waiting for any period of time.  Each meal arrived shortly after the next, all done by one beautiful, courteous Japanese woman.  Impressive. H7I6AKkYu-1jemA5cEVu4w.review_text: Possibly the best Japanese restaurant in the city of San Francisco. Go to Kappa for absolutely amazing Japanese culinary experience, however you may go home disappointed if you approach this place with the wrong expectations.  I had to think long and hard before making the difficult decision in post this review.  Why?  A 'wrong' customer going to this place would be disappoint and as the result, be frustrating to the owners.  They don't have a sign outside the building for reason.  They are not looking for a casual tourist to bump into Kappa; they can go to Mifune and Osaka-ya instead.  They are not looking to fill the place to the maximum capacity every night with a line outside the door; leave that to Sushi Zone.  They are looking to build a relationship with the regulars and present them with the best seasonal food in the comfortable cocoon that reminds you of places in Japan.  When you are inside, you could almost forget that you are in the U.S.         Kappa is a Ko-ryori specialty restaurant. 'Ko' = 'Small' 'Ryori' = 'Cuisine' Ko-ryori restaurant captures a special nitch in Japan for businessmen dining alone or two co-workers bonding over sake.  It attracts customers who care about the quality of food and sake.  Many are small, operated by a single chef serving counter seats only.  People come to places like Kappa to eat the seasonal food made from the best ingredients, with minimal handling, enjoying the taste of the ingredient.     Is it... IZAKAYA?  Nope.  Izakaya is characterized by a lively casual environment, more beer than sake, and often cheap.  In some cheap Izakaya, people order sake without caring about the brand, and eat food which is sometimes microwaved.   KAISEKI?  Nope.  Go to places like Kaygetsu (yelp.com/biz/4ok9qA8DJMC…) or Kiku of Tokyo (yelp.com/biz/MAA074Az23T…) for Kaiseki style food (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ka…).  For the most part, kaiseki involves lots of prep work, dishes that involve lots of handling.  Places like Kappa, or Tekka (yelp.com/biz/BLcV0Z4nzKL…), operating in a wife and husband team, cannot serve complex dishes.  Kaiseki is often served in Ryoutei --- which is known for private rooms.  Many come in medium size groups, often for business dinner. SUSHI?  Nope. NO SUSHI at Kappa.  Japanese visitors are often amazed by the amount of Japanese restaurants in the U.S. that serves sushi.  If you go to a town in Japan with 10 restaurants, only one would be a sushi restaurant.  Here, everyone makes sushi!  I really applaud Kappa for sticking to the roots/principles by not folding to the American customer demand.  I bet that if Kappa chef wanted to make sushi, he could make it better than 90% of the sushi chefs in San Francisco.     So, do you still want to go there?  If so, continue reading. HARD TO FIND:  I highly recommend making your first visit to Kappa with someone who has been there before.  Ever since reading Dan V.'s (danv.yelp.com) review explaining that it's on top of Denny's in J-Town, I was in a mad hunt to locate it, peeking into the Korean Bar, wondering if they are actually a Japanese restaurant.  After an extensive search, I finally found it.  They don't have any English sign on the entrance, so I needed to bravely open the wooden sliding door.  This does not mean they do not welcome non-Japanese customers.  In fact, they want all customers to enjoy their food...as long as they don't start demanding California Rolls. SEATS:  They have about 8 counter seats and one table for three.  They do take reservations. MENU:  They recommend Omakase (chef's choice) ($85) for first time visitors, which requires one day notice.  The menu is written on the wall behind the chef (in Japanese); they also have an English menu (see pictures).     I had: Sashimi (hamachi, maguro, clam) Hirame with ankimo sauce ($15) Crab sunomono ($18) Tsukune ($8) Grilled Unagi ($15) White Pickled Turnup ($15) Grilled fish Aka-miso with clams Onigiri (rice balls) with salmon Tara Shirako (cod milt) Takenoko with miso (bamboo shoot) Grilled soramame (fava bean) Maguro yamakake Nanohana Oshitashi (celery cabbage) Karashi mentaiko FOOD:  Delicious!  Owners are from Hokkaido, the northern island of Japan, known for good food.  Each dish is small, but the quality is top notch.  They try to avoid unnecessary seasoning, so most of their dishes were prepared with subtle flavoring.  Food really goes well with Sake.  They have about a dozen selections of sake, including Hakkai-san, Otoko-yama, Oni-koroshi, etc. LAST WORDS:   - Again, NO sushi. - Come alone, or with one other person.  Never in a group. - Don't come here to chow-out.  Stop by In-and-Out afterwards, if you are big eater. - Expect to spend about $60-100/person.

-pG4fm6eWoGLP6fIsFBvzw.review_text: Kappa is not your typical Japanese restaurant. What makes it special is that it focuses on omakase, which means diners let the chef decide what he thinks is best in terms of the food that he would like to serve you that night. This is an excellent dining experience for people who are serious about Japanese food. Sometimes people only associate Japanese food with fancy rolls and tons of (unnecessary) dressing that is not representative of real Japanese food. Therefore, Kappa is a breath of fresh air that gives us a glimpse into real and authentic Japanese food.  Kappa is run by a husband-and-wife team. The husband is the chef and the wife helps out in serving. All the food is prepared by the husband so you will know that everything is handled with care, as they don't hire anyone else to help out at the restaurant. The restaurant seats no more than 10 people so be sure to make a reservation.  We had excellent food such as sea urchin and whitefish in clear soup, seared tuna, scallops, etc. Each item allowed us to savor and appreciate the main ingredient used for the course. I also had the best mochi dessert at Kappa. My husband loved the green tea cheesecake and he doesn't even like desserts usually.

d32yUyhorm0uuNkW6-6YrA.review_text: Kappa is hands down one of the best dining experiences I've ever had.  The entire possible range of Japanese cuisine is explored in 7 courses hand-picked by the Chef of this husband and wife restaurant team.  I have never experienced sushi of this grade and quality anywhere - and I've had sushi all up and down the West Coast.  Honeslty, I could not begin to describe the range of incredibly flavors and textures of this meal -- hot dishes, sushi dishes, modern salads, hand-crafted desserts.  The dungeness crab was to die for.  And the sake -- the amazing sake!  The wife half of this team made the most perfect sake recommendations and provided meticulous, attentive service.  Hot towels before and after your meal, beautiful place settings.  Honestly, this place is the total experience.  To top it all off, when the wife found out it was my partner's birthday she disappeared momentarily and came back with a gift wrapped box that contained a really pretty sake glass (and no, she did not know in advance).  They are just lovely people, who have run this restaurant for 25 years, and really embody a "mom and pop" high dining, Japanese experience. GfB6sC4NJQvSI2ewbQrDNA.review_text: I went to Kappa because of a recommendation from the master of Japanese food, Nobu K, and because I like very authentic Japanese food.  When we arrived there were other people looking for the entrance too.  It's kind of hidden with only the name printed in Japanese.  We eventually found it and walked into a very small place. They greet you with the standard "Welcome" Japanese greeting and promptly seated us at the bar.  The menu behind the bar (I think it's a menu ;) )is all in Japanese but they have one menu that's translated into English.  You can order off of the menu, or they will make you "omakase" which means that the chef picks it for you.  For this you have to order one day in advance. They have one table and a sushi bar which sat about 8 people.   The atmosphere is very Japanese and we were the only couple at the Sushi bar speaking English.  It really reminded me about my trip to Japan.   They start with a piece of fish (think it was salmon) which was cooked in a small bowl.  Very tasty and cooked to perfection. We had the Hirame with salted seaweed.  This was amazing.  The seaweed and the sauce it had complimented the fish perfectly. The next dish has a bit of a story behind it.  So, I thought that I'd order one of the specials which she said was "fish roe".  It sounded interesting and I like fish eggs. When we get the dish, it looks like kind of small sacks.  It was really slimy in a sauce and some onions.  We tried it and it tasted good but the consistency was really strange.  We tried to also pick it up various times with our chopsticks in small pieces but it kept attaching itself to our chopsticks with these huge slimy sacks.  We asked her again what it was and she said "you know the female fish, well this is the male" Well, at that point we determined that we were eating fish "sperm" but we tried to not say anything between us so that way we can try getting it down.  It was really difficult and I didn't want to seem like we didn't like it, because that can be translated as an insult in Japan. Eventually, after about 4 dishes, she finally took it away and we mentioned that we were just "full".  Authentic, from what I have seen especially Japan, means eating all types of things that we are not accustomed to, and this one definitely was on the edge.   Then we had: Japanese Bamboo with a spicy green Miso sauce  - Amazingly tasty and the sauce was perfect.  The bamboo was very juicy A few select pieces of sushi which the chef picked for us.  It was amazing and melted in our mouth's.  I usually never eat sashimi but this was VERY flavorful and tender.  Cut perfectly and not a bit of fat in it. Grilled Unagi --- Probaby the best Unagi I've ever had.  It was cooked to perfection right on the skin.  Very tasty and tender. We were pretty full, but they suggested we try some type of Beef stew.  The Beef was so tender and tasty and it came with some vegetables and potatoes.  Amazing and I couldn't believe how light it was.  When we ordered it we asked for a small order and he said "no".  He knew that we could stomach it down. She suggested that we try the Mochi for dessert.  It had red bean paste in it and at one point we bit into a strawberry.  It was amazing!   We also had some amazing Daigingo Sake, I had 2 Soju's which she recommended and some Green tea which was very good. This place isn't for everyone, especially if you don't have an open mind.  If you are a typical American which craves X mixed with X in some kind of roll this place isn't for you.  It was AMAZING and as soon as I get my next bonus check, I'll be running back. :) No more fish sperm for me!  ;) Update: flickr.com/photos/marc00… So check this out, I found a photo of it on Flickr, it's called Shirako and it actually means "white children".   It's a delicacy in Japan.

Yz6VVf1KhzbiZU9mvxsb9Q.review_text: What can I say ?  I simply do not understand the 4 and a half rating, assuming most reviewers were qualified foodies. The bad:  Ebi shioyaki was not prepared from live spot prawn but previously frozen from any Asian market.  Kurobuta was the toughest I have tasted.  For much more tender version, try Sushi Sam in San Mateo.  Grilled chicken meat ball was served cold and tasteless.  Kazu in SF uses organic chciken meat made fresh as you ordered.  The ugly:  Marinaded kampachi was overly salty, with a strong fishy taste.  How about trying black cod in miso broth at Bonzu in downtown SF.  When asked to substituted for my friend who has food allergy, my friend received 2 pieces of daikon in place of frozen crab meat.  Not acceptable. 3S53VaMDPy8Lywk2TuPb4A.review_text: This is such a unique dining experience.  My dinner companion had eaten there before.  We have visited numerous restaurants and she suggested that I would enjoy Kappa. I phoned and made a reservation.  The hostess asked me to phone the day before to communicate if we would be dining prix fixe or ordering a la carte.  I asked my companion what she had previously done there and she said prix fixe.  So, I phoned Kappa and communicated our choice to the hostess. We had a quick drink at the Playground next door and then went to Kappa.  As stated in other reviews, it is tucked away upstairs over what used to be the Japantown Denny's. This is a very small restaurant.  I think it seats a total of 14.  Ten seats at the "bar" and a small private room for 4.  It is only open from 6 pm to 10 pm (closed on Sundays).  The last seating is at 8 pm. It is a intimate space. Many restaurants have friendly service.  The service at Kappa goes beyond friendly.  It is kind.  It truly does feel like you are being invited into the home of the husband and wife team.  He is the chef.  She helps with preparation and provides front of the house service.  She is very patient.  She explains each dish.  She keeps the meal moving along without any sense of rushing the process.   Overall, the food was very good.  I do agree with a comment I read in another review that it might be nice if there were a few more warm dishes.  I am not going to provide great detail on every single dish.  But, I will quickly cover them. It is a unique set of courses. Course #1 Eggplant with dried bonito This was a delicate dish.  The eggplant was tender without being mushy. tinyurl.com/4326jhb Course #2 Dungeness crab with vinegar sauce This was very good.  The tartness of the vinegar sauce was such a great background for the sweetness of the dungeness crab. tinyurl.com/3up7vn7 tinyurl.com/3k7w7n2 Course $3 Asparagus with sesame paste This was a enjoyable dish.  There is a grittiness to sesame paste that I do not prefer.  However, with the asparagus it worked well. tinyurl.com/3zn2lut Course #4 Mixed Plate - I am going to try and remember what each item on the plate was.  Rock cod, duck, squid wrapped around some type of spicy seafood, a type of fish I do not remember, egg, pork roll, whole prawn, tofu, sweet corn fritter, chicken ball on stick, hamachi This was a very eclectic plate.  For the most part, it was an excellent culinary experience.  The squid was a little tough.  The chicken had a very unique texture.  I am still not sure whether I enjoyed it or not.  The tofu was the first tofu I've ever eaten that I thoroughly enjoyed.  I would have preferred the duck to have been heated. tinyurl.com/3nopls2 tinyurl.com/3qat2xo Course #5 - Sushi (hamachi, bluefin, yellow-jack) - I boycott bluefin tuna.  However, it looked amazing.  My friend does not boycott it so she was able to eat hers and mine.  The other sushi on this plate was very fresh and well cut.   tinyurl.com/3zel3el Course #6 - Sushi (toro, unagi, clam) - This was an amazing plate of sushi.  The toro had a nice touch of smokiness.  The unagi was simply perfect.  The clam combined with the fresh green was a excellent combination. tinyurl.com/43cylky Course #7 - Dessert - This was a dessert trio plus a ice cream with cheesecake and mango.  One part of the trio was a mochi dessert. I do not really enjoy mochi.  The remainder was very much to my liking.  The cheesecake with ice cream and mango was a heavenly dessert.  It was so good that I forgot to take a photo. tinyurl.com/3twtc4h Overall - The food was very good.  But what really brings this together is the intimacy of feeling as if you are truly being served a meal from very kind hosts.  It is a unique evening.  I will note though.  If you plan on taking a guest insure they are adventurous with cuisine.  We both are and, for us, another part of the experience is trying different dishes.

XOFEzOrwphwy_wfa66Sezw.review_text: Kappa Japanese restaurant has very traditional cuisine. A Japanese couple is operating this very quiet little restaurant. The dishes were so good. We love their food.

ZMocFA2lNMJeiKjguUKu7g.review_text: It was like finding some old Japanese ruin. "Look for a light," people said, and I wondered if I was in a Miyazaki film or something. Was the cat bus going to come and take me there?  So my friend is getting married and asked me to be groomsmen, so we can here to celebrate!  Kampai! My only complaint was the private party of frat boys behind me who were swearing, drinking beer, and talking so loudly I could barely hear my friend.  Nothing against frat boys, I lived in a frat house during my undergrad, but these guys were jerks and made my meal unpleasant since I could barely hear how my friend got engaged. Back to the meal, it was, well fun. We had a lot of small "fun" dishes like fried corn, crab sunomono, scallop salad, strawberry sorbet. EQ-fPVMNGhwZOdB8PJ25ug.review_text: pretty good place. intimate and unassuming.   try the tsukue, satsumaage, delectable sardines, and of course, the unagi.  super nice people working there.   not that super high end but expect to pay a grip here

txWFXIMtDUaheiePKnAQyg.review_text: Want to go to Japan without the expense and time?  Just go to Kappa.  The interior is exactly like a small restaurant in Japan - everything wood, screens, a long sushi bar and a table just big enough for our party of 4 off to the side.  And the food.  We had omakase - eggplant with bonito flakes; crab meat with cucumbers and sesame seeds; asparagus with miso paste; a plate filled with single bites of monkfish liver, shrimp, tofu covered in some kind of crunchy rice, duck, chicken meatball, pork, and other seafoody things I can't remember; sashimi; and hamachi and unagi rolls.  Everything was delicious and fresh.  I don't even really like seafood, but the unagi and hamachi rolls were amazing - both melted in your mouth.  Dessert was two different kinds of mochi and ice cream with green tea mousse.  It is a little challenging to find . . .  the address is technically 1700 Post.  But if you walk off the street into 1700 Post, you'll find yourself in Dimples, some seedy bar.  Which I did.  You actually have to go around the corner from Dimples and up some stairs to get to Kappa.  Definitely expensive too.  But you're really paying for an experience, not just a meal.  And it's a 2.5 hour experience so be prepared for some sore legs at the end of it.

ibvH1Y7Rh_tstiWgH0OFTA.review_text: I'm going to make the post on this restaurant brief, straightforward and to the point as I can tell that many have already gone in depth with very precise details about this cute little charming spot!  The wife and husband have been open for 18 years at this little place, very tiny as everyone has mentioned, but I liked the feel. I did not feel claustrophobic whatsoever. Everyone is treated with a lot of attention and food arrives very quickly in a very delicate manner. No arrogant feel, the owners are very kind, welcoming, and warm - keeping a warm smile along with class.   Dishes are pricey but this place is the definition of Japanese fine dining. You will find a variety of cooked dishes as well as cold dishes and good sashimi (they go to the Hayward fish market just a side note).   I want to come here again for the omakase but point taken - it is pretty expensive here. Just a few dishes will easily make its tab up to a few hundred dollars or so. (or omakase = $85/person).  People who don't think this place is good are probably people who only dine at sushi places that serve rolls, nigiri and call the cooked food chicken/beef teriyaki. No sir, this place is not like that at all. Rather, dishes will consist of Japanese delicacies such as Simmered Sardine, Grilled Fish, Grilled Unagi, Sea Snail, Crab sunomono, etc.  Hits: you MUST get the GRILLED UNAGI! Very good

KI7gPbRvdngGcgq3-RD7Gw.review_text: A treat for not just your tastebuds, but your whole being!    The boyfriend took me here for a belated valentine's day dinner (good work, bf! and yes, i'm behind on my reviews).  I found very enjoyable for the both of us to be able hand over control and share the experience of feeling like a kids again.  So, I definitely recommend "omakase" (where the chef choose your dishes for you).   $85/person is a lot, but quality of food is amazing.  Each "koryori" dish is bite-sized, but each is painstakingly crafted and ingredients taste undeniably fresh.  Plus, given you get about 7 plates worth -- it really is worth it. Lf7MRy1_uFxgKUYn6ov5yw.review_text: A very solid 4-star review. Loved the experience. Highly recommend it. But probably won't come back.  Kappa is a lovely small Japanese restaurant. The bar seats 10 and there is a back room for parties of 4-6. They appear to do only one seating per night. My GF and I showed up early (6:30PM) and were the first to be seated. The service was impeccable. We never felt rushed, she answered all of my detailed questions, and she made some wonderful recommendations for sake. The food was quite amazing. We got the more expensive omakase and were glad that we did. My favorite dishes were the sweet corn tempura and the braised pumpkin in soy sauce. I must have spent 15 minutes slowly eating and savoring the sweet corn tempura.... sigh. They have an amazing sake selection, but it's by the carafe. We probably spent $125-$150 just on sake. Do yourself a favor and buy a very nice bottle to bring to the restaurant. The $20/bottle corkage fee is well worth it.

ZcXKAvTSPFgHay788z3pMA.review_text: This place was heaven. The food was amazing. There were several times that evening where I said, oh, that's what that is supposed to taste like. NXvOzqZpj-7NFjOmxN8tzg.review_text: Loved my visit here at Kappa.   As a native Japanese, I expect a lot from those reputable Japanese restaurants in the Bay Area. Being in South Bay, we have access to many good Japanese restaurants that are considered to be pretty authentic. I live in South Bay for the Japanese communities, restaurants, grocery stores and other Japanese resources (including my job).  Because of that, I don't really know many good Japanese restaurants or do not expect to find anything as good in SF. Even my Japanese friends in SF admit they come to South Bay for better Japanese food.   After living in the bay area for 15+ years, this is the first time I've heard of this place. And I'm definitely glad I visited. Maybe some Japanese people wouldn't appreciate or consider this place as greatly as I do. But I definitely appreciated its quiet and authentic atmosphere, and of course the food.   You see those photos people have already posted, and what you see on the photos are pretty much what you get. Certain dishes may change depending on the seasons, but it will be pretty close to those photos. But they are all good. It gave me the nostalgic feeling eating some of their food as it reminded me of my mom's food. But at the same time, some of the dishes were so well prepared and beautiful that you know you could not get some of their food at home in Japan (and believe me, my mom is a very good cook). Just like Kaiseki food, you can tell the chef has spent a lot of time and effort making these dishes. The service his wife provides definitely complements his food. She's very attentive, polite yet pleasant. There was a customer who was sitting at the counter alone, and I thought the wife was being a great companion for him by having an enjoyable yet polite conversation. The chef is rather quiet, but when he speaks, he's also very nice. From the moment she greets you at the entrance, it feels like you're in a Koryouri restaurant in Japan.   Honestly, I did not think I could get such a quality and traditional Japanese food in SF Japantown where it has become a multi Asian cultural spot. Their food was delicious from the starter to dessert (even their green tea was great). As we leave, the wife walked us to the door and thanked us for the visit. You will not regret your visit here in any ways. The whole experience was so pleasant and we're already looking forward to coming back.   We originally tried to make a reservation at Kiss Seafood, but they never picked up the phone so were not able to make a reservation.  Well, I have to say now I'm glad they didn't pick up the phone because we were able to have such pleasant experience at Kappa instead.

zKJWcAJAPCdHcnJEDdOHEQ.review_text: The omakase is a bit pricey but it deserves the money. I've tried omakase in asian countries and this is similar to what I have experienced, maybe even better because of the private and quiet atmosphere.  Total for 2 $222 tips included.

KUusL15g7gVmPO7_XRp8cQ.review_text: Clean. Small. Extremely nice wife-husband dream team. NOT a sushi restaurant.  Kappa serves Koryori style food which is a traditional Japanese cuisine mostly consisting of cooked food. they do a small sashimi platter which is beautiful but usually no sushi is served.   Presentations were beautiful and I loved the ambiance. It reminded me of being back in Tokyo so for a second I forgot I was in SF.  Highly recommended to all who want to try something a lil different from sushi.  Prices are quite steep tho so prepare to open your wallet for an amazing experience in return! ;)

IPzVg0wE9EW2_VfJI0Uzgg.review_text: Big tip: you've read that they're upstairs from the Dennys in Japantown. However, you also need to know that the entrance is an unassuming sliding door which absolutely does not say "OPEN," "restaurant", or even "KAPPA" (unless you can read the small unlit Japanese sign off to the side).   You *will* think you've walked up the wrong flight of stairs, or it's closed.  But then you open the sliding door, and the hostess comes to greet you, and you know you've found the place.  A real gem. The food is great and the hospitality and service are unmatched. I can't think of another restaurant in SF where I can have excellent food and feel relaxed. The menu is varied, with specials that change frequently. You either go for the prix fixe menu at $75/person or a la carte, with entrees around $15-$20.  The team that works behind the counter, I imagine they're husband and wife, are so in sync it's like watching a ballet as they prepare dishes in near silence. They're quite welcoming and will talk to you, ask you what you like, where you're from, what your family name is, and so on. It's unlike any restaurant I've been to in the US; I felt more like a guest of a family in Japan.  The restaurant is tiny - there's a sushi-style bar that seats 10, maybe, and at least one small private room that looks like it might seat 4 - 6.  As others have mentioned, Kappa does not serve sushi (and they're likely to tell you this as you enter, just to make sure you're not disappointed). They do have sashimi though and while I haven't tried it, I expect it is very good.  Five stars for the food, two stars for the warm hospitality and attentive service.

W9G_MVW_KBe5BQlbSOmYUg.review_text: I was skeptical about this place meeting expectations but thankfully I was not disappointed. The food was great and I like the atmosphere.
