XHmsNa9tHPk8yt_MmkXREA.review_text: A bit of a hole in the wall, but in a good way.  Had a relaxing course with my family and enjoyed every bite. Great service and wide variety of small dishes. The fresh persimmon in the dessert was refreshing. My favorite tastes were the sea urchin and the crab. Will be going again in a couple of months.

ggk1thd4F2hlhc9JdspTRA.review_text: Went here for a dinner for an authentic high quality Japanese dinners around. For those who know where Japantown Denny's is, it's just right above, on the second floor, and look for a yellow lantern light there as many have indicated. The place is quite small. It seats around no more than 8 or 10 people, so I booked reservations around 2 hours advance before the place opens at 6pm.   Decided on the $85 Omakase (chef pre-selected dinner) beforehand too, which we had to request one day in advance (at least). We were greeted warmly by the husband wife owners/chefs. The Omakase came with around 9 small dishes. But the fish, veggies and asparagus were very fresh.. Each dishes were presented nicely and care. The chef and server also perfectly interacted with each of the customers. The standout dishes from what I remembered were the Shitake Broth, Maguro, Fish Liver and Strawberry Sorbet for dessert.   We spent around $220 for two people after tip given the effort the put to prep, present and serve the food and interact with customers.   Probably will come back in the very distant future. Certainly glad I came and it was a very pleasant and enjoyable experience. It reminds me of a typical small traditional mom pop restaurants in Japan.

Dd9NqLdmDnXERovE37dcuA.review_text: I've lived and eaten my way through SF for over 15 years. Truly, this is one of San Francisco's most unique dining experiences.   Call at least a day ahead for the Omakase (Chef's Menu). Most everything they serve is flown in from Japan. Amazing! The owner/chef is truly a culinary artist and his wife/hostess is both charming and helpful. This is not a "wolf down a California roll before a movie" kind of meal. This is a time honored tradition of each taking time with every course, appreciating each bite, and relaxing before the next course. If you're not adventurous, move on. But if you lump yourself into the "foodie" category, it's a must try.   How this place isn't packed every single night is a mystery to me.

4lAVKVISeiwPPAyy2Tk9ug.review_text: Every Japanese food lover should try Kappa at least once. They do Koryouri, traditional Japanese small plates, which is pretty rare in the US. The whole restaurant holds only about 10 people. I'd recommend going with 2 people and sitting at the counter. You'll need to get a reservation for omakase a few days in advanced. Expect to spend about $250. The two owners are a couple and prepare each dish directly in front of you. The lady wears a serving kimono and the man a head chef outfit. Every dish is petite, elegant, and extremely simple -  It's a wonderful experience.

DS0Idr2XDhz5e7ZfSy0dYA.review_text: I've only been to Kappa once, and it was on September 7, 2003. Granted this info is old, but judging from the more recent reviews, this place has not lost its touch, identity, or reputation and quality.  The restaurant is a lot smaller than what it appears to be from their website. The interior was quite upscale, but the intimacy and atmosphere created by the husband and wife operation, in addition to top notch service, made the dining experience even more memorable.  Rumiko-san (wife of the chef who was our server) was a delight and very helpful in recommending dishes and translating some of the menu items on the wall. Tell her what category you are interested in and she can check with availability on the wall or ask her husband (the chef).  On with what was ordered (a mix of regular menu and special wall items):  1) Tamba Kuro-mame - This is a special black bean from Japan (supposedly the bean is named after a region, Tamba). Very large sized and apparently cooked over 2 days until the right texture is obtained. Then they are soaked in a mix of sake and presumably sugar (I was able to taste box sake and something really sweet). A wonderful appetizer/dessert/palate cleanser which had a delicate aftertaste. Rumiko-san was saying that this is a high end dish in Japan, typically served during special occassions (like New Year's). We liked the black beans so much we ordered two glasses!  2) Maguro sashimi - 5 nice pieces of good aka maguro. I didn't try anything else, but the maguro wasn't as good if you went to the better sushi-ya's in the bay area (Ino, Toshi's, Sakae's, Sawa's etc).   3) Thinly sliced yamaimo. I was expecting some sort of cooked yam but to our surprise it came out in delicate thin slices, served raw with some shredded nori on top. Rumiko recommended dipping some soy sauce with some of the fresh wasabi on the side. Tasted wonderful though it was a bit slimey on the side (that is how the raw yamaimo is...probably an aquired taste). Note: I'm sure I would enjoy this way more now.  4) Grilled chicken meatballs - 3 skewers, each with two meatballs. Very flavorful and I think there is more than just chicken in it! Served with a light brown sauce that complements the dish.  5) Grilled black pork (kurobota) - yakiniku style thinly sliced pork. VERY delicious, juicy, and tasty. Lots of finely chopped green onion (or chive...arguable as it was very thin) and some sesame seed.  6) Grilled Matsutake - This was quite a treat (but very expensive for 4 pieces...$20 for this dish alone!) It was dirty white looking but more so light brown after being cooked. My first time having matsutake.  7) A simmered vegetable dish (greens) in broth with tofu skin and some spices.  8) Miso soup - red miso with a touch of green onion and what appeared to be cilantro stems.  9) A very big piece of mentaiko onigiri, served with finely chopped greens (stems) and one yellow pickle.   I believe that was it. Everything was amazing, service was excellent (the chef came out and personally bowed to thank us when we left, and Rumiko-san walked us out of the door to greet us farewell), and a good feeling overall The meal was $110 after tips for two people, without drinks. I still remember that meal to this day, that's how wonderful the experience was.   I need to go back again, so that I can put this place and Nami Nami in Mountain View (if I ever get to go for dinner), into their right equivalent perspectives. Kappa has the edge of the more personable and intimate setting, while NN's decor is more upbeat and izakaya-esque.

VH921HuaETsT2bmRBZ9Zew.review_text: my boyfriend took me here for my birthday and i loved it!  yes, it's somewhat hidden and challenging to fine but once you enter the sliding door, it's like you've entered a different world.  we had the omakase and it was amazing.  all of the fish just melts in your mouth.  and for cooked dished that night, we had don-kat-su, duck, chicken meatball, seaweed soup and lamb.  all amazing.  and they even gave me a sake glass as a birthday present!  will def find another special occasion to go back.

FAeIsKkBeXvpQpj6Zc29iQ.review_text: i don't like scallops. i don't like oysters. uni is generally unappetizing. and i wrinkle my nose at red bean anything. BUT my meal at kappa included all the aforementioned and i LOVED it all.  funny how that works. all 4.5-star-yelp-bias aside, this place was impressive. down to the very last details: their oshibori towels are full-size fluffy martex face towels as opposed to threadbare mini-towels you might find at other places. and you get one before and after your meal. their napkins are from williams sonoma: fancy! and when refilling our tea cups, the lady put our cup on her little tray and filled it, instead of reaching over us to pour. and she and her husband were a generally sweet and pleasant host couple.  as for the food, yea, i got the impression that some of the food wasn't freshly shipped in from japan that morning as a lot of seafood was left sitting in the case. but whatever, it tasted excellent and i didn't get sick. no real need to list off what i ate since i imagine the omakase menu changes often, but i did enjoy all of it (except maybe one piece of marinated/smoked fish that was a tad too salty). also, someone in our group is allergic to shellfish and the substitutes weren't bad at all. and we left very satisfied and wanting to come back.  what else. oh, kappa isn't that hard to find. it's just that the outer door leading to it is mis-labeled, so you think you've gone to the wrong place. it's just at the top of the stairs above denny's. the door on the right goes into playground. the door on the left goes into kappa. just ignore the "club nishiki" lettering on the window and proceed through the wooden sliding door.

BblbmWuODTQ369leBu4o4g.review_text: Kappa is a sensational experience for new lovers.  A small, hidden, and unpretentious restaurant in Japantown - this authentic restaurant dazzles the senses with it many courses.  Gents - Just go all out. Koryori style.   (For the unenlightened: "Koryori" is the Japanese equivalent of tapas style cuisine.)  I was dating a Japanese gal when I first found this place.  She was my interpreter to the cute couple that run this place.    "What do you think?" I asked my date.  "It's better than the real thing," she said.  (Home run, boys.  Home run.)

I6-bQXALn5HhEg68VMzApQ.review_text: Definitely lived up to the hype.  Lovely husband and wife team did all the work.  Very accommodating couple-last member of our party of 5 could not make it and Rumiko said that was fine.  We were stuffed by plate number 5 and had 2 more plates to go (which included dessert).  Reserved for mom's birthday and was presented with silk bag made by Rumiko's mother!  Very nice touch.  Went with the omakase or chef's tasting menu of small plates: hearty miso soup, asparagus with sesame sauce, fresh crab in cucumber vinegrette, large tasting platter which included monkfish liver pate (delicacy), fresh sashimi with the sweetest uni ever, tonkatsu with a huge crabcake, and finally dessert consisting of 2 platters, homemade green mochi with red bean center with vanilla ice cream with green tea powder garnish followed by side of fresh pear and papaya.  Yum!  Tried one sake and generous amount poured for the evening (party doesn't drink).  Owners were so attentive and were filling our green tea and hot water glasses.  My party and one other guest were the only ones in attendance in the small establishment for early dinner and that's the way we liked it!   Our party was so large, unable to chat with the owners but great atmosphere.  Would have liked some traditional music in the background, but maybe that would have made it too commercial? Difficult to locate but check out the previous postings for photos (adjacent to Playground entrance, through sliding wooden door-thank goodness the telltale lantern was lit-next to club Nishiki?).  Would love to go back esp. if somebody else paid this time, not cheap.  Party of 4 with one sake came to $348.44.

A02ryK2u5hA_ANkErNjuCA.review_text: My buddy and I come here all the time during the day for mid day or early afternoon lunch. I am amazed that this place is not busier than it is, as the service, food and prices are always exceptional. The only thing that I would find fault with is that sometimes the young ladies that work there have language difficulties, but they always are very accommodating and try their best to make sure you are efficiently and quickly served with deliciously served food. My buddy and I whom I always go with usually go for the lunch box specials, which are quite filling and are priced very moderately. I highly recommend this place. It's a great place and is a great reprieve from the "brush" and "lackluster" Chinese Restaurant close by that has extremely rude service..P.S..I love their Pork and Chicken Ton Katsu dishes.

jSmcODsZ3QiAehNlpfH50Q.review_text: San Francisco's best kept secret. So wonderful. Makes me miss Japan.

m077SPgDrTwQBhUlP7xSOQ.review_text: When I first walked through the very hidden sliding door of Kappa, I felt like I was entering an underground club, feeling like I was in need of the right password to get in.  Then a woman in a kimono and smile welcomes us, making everyone feel privileged for being one of the lucky 10 people there.  Kappa is a hidden gem, and I almost feel bad for blabbing the secret out on Yelp but I won't be selfish.  There are many dishes on the menu you won't find at any other Japanese restaurant, making it a truly unique dining experience.  I recommend this restaurant to anyone that appreciates Japanese flavors and cuisine outside of sushi.  (no sushi served here)  So bring an adventurous pallet, someone who can speak Japanese (it certainly helped us) and don't forget your Visa, as you'll be spending at least $75 per person.  Enjoy, but please save me a seat!

DKmUukETiMVidu548TE-zw.review_text: If I had gone to Kappa on a different day, I might have liked it more.  But I went on a day when the other dining guests (the place fits like 8 people, so it's always gonna be just you vs. them) were the most obnoxious, annoying, loud MOFOs.  They probably would have been okay, boasting about their restaurants and career and knowledge on Japanese food, if I were sitting next to them at Cheesecake factory or something.  But for god's sake, it's just us and them, and I felt like we were trapped in an elevator with a frat boy belching out the alphabet for two hours.   The chef and the wife/waitress were nice and I enjoyed watching them prepare food. They had very cute dishware and utensils.  (ah, maybe one day my dining table will enjoy something like that)  But it could be awkward at times when you feel like the waitress is watching you (probably true) and waiting for you to finish your dish (probably not true).  It got especially awkward for me when she started asking me about the difference between Chinese food and Japanese food.  I wish, I truly wish I had some decent knowledge to offer on the subject but I don't, and I really didn't want to sound like a traitor and tell her I actually prefer Japanese food over Chinese any day.   We had the Omakase.  The most memorable dish was the crab meat, juicy chunky crab meat stuffed into two tight sushi rolls, and more juicy chunky crab meat on the side.  Boyfriend said he has never liked crab as much as this.   Some dishes I like the presentation more than the taste: the large plate with 9 different items on it.  Some meat were rather rubbery.  Maybe if they kept their portions smaller, it would have tasted better.   Overall, I felt the dishes weren't as delicate as Kiss Seafood and the environment not as pleasant.  But if someone wants to take me to Kappa, I'd definitely go again.

wKPCISrVLeUfGoOhpUCKKg.review_text: The service was excellent. The waiter was super nice. Plus the sashimi was super fresh and tasty, even when they were about to close

shfhrdFn8aGgFP8dyXNyxg.review_text: Kappa was a great experience. The service was incredible - the most attentive and authentic I've experienced outside of Japan with none of the unpleasant behavior so common among the proprietors of Japanese restaurants in the city. We ordered Omakase (chef's choice) and had a number of great dishes. I thought too many of them were chilled and too much emphasis on various seafood dishes without enough rice or veggies to balance them. A few items actually didn't taste good. I'd still give Kappa another try. A beautiful, small, intimate, and unassuming small space.

a2E7Knfh7jEW8rupPafP3g.review_text: There are too many reviews about this place so i am trying my best to make it short and get to the points:  PROS: -Nice little restaurant (10 seats by the bar in total served by 1 chef and 1 server)  -The server was very attentive, dressed up in complete set of kimono which is very rare in US  -8 course for $85 is very competitive price (1 soup, 2 app, 1 main entree, 1 sashimi, 1 sushi, 1 dessert, 1 fruit plate)  -Every course was presented well with nice dinnerware  -Located in Japantown which is quiet but very safe at night  CONS: -The restaurant only provides multiple course menu and require one day in advance reservation, not very convenient for travelers.  -You can order extra sushi/sashimi to go with your multi-course menu only but not just sushi/sashimi there (don't know why ?)  This is bit sad for me cos i like these two most among all courses and seems this is the chef 's background as well  -the main entree (hot food) came out bit cold and dry.  Since this is a two people running operation, most of the hot food was prepared ahead of time and reheated for us when ready to serve.  I would recommend to people who never have Japanese multiple course dinner before, but once is enough.

jydBnjVv3V0tg_CXZIU91w.review_text: Impeccable service, and the food was expertly prepared.  You know you are in a high end place, when you are served REAL wasabi, not the paste or powder stuff.  The Omakase was plenty of food, and every taste expertly crafted.  The presentation and ambiance reminded me of Tokyo, and it is definitely a place you have to go to since it is unique in the bay area.  I will definitely return!

kg49IgzsS7-C7d2AaY-c9A.review_text: I like that I don't have to order anything at this place... they take very good care of you from beginning to finish.  I walked away full and very very satiated....  I wish there were more celebration occasions for me to come here...

i55-mHGx31A5rpFrrdnqKA.review_text: Good food - but like many have said - it is overpriced for what it is.  Nice couple that has been doing this for a long time. Its a really small place and we went on a Monday and were one of the only ones there.  Service was good - though since it was a Monday - I think the food came pretty quick so they could go home early.  But essentially - if this was $20-30 less per person - i would say this place is 5 stars..

cI15fqq7P13Vp7A3xc3lQA.review_text: I came here in Aug '08 with a friend from Tokyo who was here on business, and after a week in the Midwest he was dying for quality Japanese food, his treat and he didn't care about price.  I had read good things about Kappa, and when we walked in it indeed felt like we were back in Tokyo.  Unfortunately, when it came to the food we were both disappointed.  As it turns out, Kappa caters primarily to a clientele of Japanese visiting SF on business, and we happened to come during Obon season (festival season in Japan) when most Japanese are vacationing with family and business travel is limited.  As a result, business at Kappa was slow, all of this explained to us by the hostess.  What this meant for us though, was that the sashimi was not very fresh.  We didn't mind paying high prices, but you expect quality in return, and I have to say, the tako (octopus) sashimi actually tasted like it had already turned bad, which was unacceptable, especially at $90 for the sashimi platter (sad to say, but I had much fresher sashimi in the $6.95 bento lunch special across the street at Takara).  We dined a la carte, none of the dishes were remarkable, came to $250 for two and we only had a couple small bottles of beer and didn't leave particularly full or satisfied.  My friend said that if Kappa were in Japan it would not survive.

RVJEM5wqx9_LYM30LEZhkw.review_text: Genuinely Japanese.  Highest quality and attention to detail.  I found it extremely relaxing, and the food was excellent.  Service was very good too.

nMvd0T2l4CdRCd8KlYc_sg.review_text: This entrance is upstairs right next to Playground karaoke and easy to miss.   GOOD: - Small, intimate setting. There are like 10-12 seats along the bar, and a table for 4 on the side. - The place is run by a husband/wife combo. The wife does all the serving and is very nice.  JUST OK: - The food is average to good but few of the dishes were exceptional. Most dishes are COOKED. This is NOT a sushi/sashimi omakase so keep that in mind if you are looking for raw seafood.   BAD: - I'm all for Japanese cooked food but this place is horrendously OVERPRICED and inefficient. There is only one cook/chef (the husband) and he makes all these little different dishes so of course, it is a very labor intensive process. If a recipe needs chopped onions or panko bread crumbs, it is going to be the husband doing all the chopping and toasting. So essentially, you are paying a premium for this one guy to do everything. And you don't need to be an expert to do prep work so don't kid yourself and think that your food is any better because the chef owner chopped your onions instead of some cheap labor. There is a reason why all restaurants in the city have immigrant workers in the back. - Because the chef/owner husband is doing all the food prep, he is too busy to converse with the clients. What is the point in having a personal chef if you can't chat with him? - Many of the dishes are simple and cheap in terms of ingredients. Asparagus in sesame paste? A piece of TAMAGO? A piece of FISH CAKE? PORK KATSU? Really? I'm not paying $85 for things I can make myself or that I can buy in a supermarket with the same quality. Even if these dishes are all made from scratch, they use cheap ingredients and do not involve expert skills to make. Yet, they still probably take hours to produce because as I said, there is only ONE person doing all the cooking and food prep.  CONCLUSION: Kappa is a TERRIBLE VALUE and not worth $85 at all. If this place was in NYC, this ridiculous pricing (for what you get) would not fly because there are other Koryori or Kaiseki places that use premium ingredients and make better dishes (no tamago!) for a similar price point or cheaper. Unfortunately, there are too many people in SF who don't know better or are willing to overpay so Kappa's rating is inaccurate and overinflated.

XSQZ9irNk8UUwWOEEu6rkA.review_text: This place is super expensive and I had super high expectations.  Why wouldn't I - it's totally hidden, I heard about it only by word of mouth, and it's by reservations only.  We ordered the Omakase since it was our first time,  The food and presentation were decent, but not to die for,  We had spectacular service, but that could be due to the fact that we were the only ones eating there that evening!!!

f6dRSiywqXr8joviPkvinw.review_text: It's a tiny little place, but one of the most personal experiences I've had in San Francisco. The husband and wife owner are amazingly adept at handling the diners--she usually speaks to the English-speaking ones, and he defers to his Japanese clientele.   I came  here a few years ago and this restaurant single-handedly changed my entire opinion about eggplant. Now, I actually like, after having been served a snow white whole japanese eggplant (it had been peeled) with a lump of ginger and a little soy. The flesh was creamy and tasted ever so slightly of smoke. And the spareness of the ginger and soy was perfect.   It's price-y, so I hadn't been back until recently and was immediately reminded why the price is worth it. Tsukune--three skewers of tender, lightly spiced chicken meatballs are wonderful; as is the more "upscale" hiramo (halibut) with ankimo sauce--the monkfish liver has been blended to creaminess, almost like a cross between a creamy ceviche and vitello al tonnato, an Italian favorite of mine.  The woman never blinked an eye when we ordered spicy cod roe sac, served either seared, or as the Japanese eat them, just straight up. There's nothing like it--bitter, spicy, soft, chewy, all at once, and a warning--the texture is almost like raw sausage.  Sunonomo, a traditional Japanese cucumber salad that is lightly dressed in vinegar, came heavily dressed in freshly picked Dungeness crab. It was a big bowl, and that with the chicken meatballs may have been enough.  The only thing she gave us a sideways eye for ordering (and admittedly, we ordered it because it was not on the menu and we saw the Japanese pair next to us order it specially) was a raw squid tossed with pureed squid belly, sake, and shiso. It's kind of a murky purplish-grayish-brownish. Not recommended.  The sake collection can also not be missed. It's great--ask for a good suggestion, they will willingly guide you.  This is by far one of the best, most honest Japanese meals I've had in the city.

LWs6pc7l8BxhVkULbtHBwA.review_text: EXCELLENT OMAKASE! (THE OMAKASE AT KAPPA IS PRE-FIXED MENU KORYORI STYLE) They have a selection of single portion items if you prefer to order your own dishes. Their Omakase costs $85.00 per person, this restaurant is probably the most expensive Japanese restaurant in Japantown and well worth it.  The couple there operating that restaurant is very friendly, old fashioned, and formal, and this restaurant is very calm and relaxing. RESTAURANT RULES AT KAPPA: 1) Reservations are available either by email or by phone. 2) For Omakase (pre-fixed menu) must be requested AT LEAST 1 day in advance. 3) Same day reservations by PHONE ONLY (After 4:30 pm). NO EMAILS allowed. MY SUGGESTIONS AT KAPPA 1) Reserve their Omakase.  It has lots of variety of primarily good quality fish and vegetables.   2) To see an example of what their Omakase looks like go to: yelp.com/biz_photos/kapp… 3) Kappa is very hidden out.  To find it at the stairs on 1706 Post Street walk to the top of the stairs, 4) Walk through the left door that says Kappa 5) Look for this light when you walk in yelp.com/biz_photos/kapp… 6) Below the light near the door handle you will see a small sign that says KAPPA. 7) Grab the loop ring looking door handle and slide it open. 8) You will hear some bells jingle and a Japanese woman wearing a Kimono will come over and great you. SO IF YOUR IN JAPANTOWN SAN FRANCISCO AND YOU'RE LOOKING FOR A VERY AUTHENTIC HIGH END JAPANESE RESTAURANT WITH GOOD FISH AND VEGETABLES THEN KAPPA IS THE PLACE!

qY1crTEAG__vaqBsn2_rYA.review_text: Intimate setting  Make sure you book ahead of time  A bit hard to find the door - its upstairs from Denny's  Clean and delicious food  Everything is made from scratch  Each bite and taste is crafted by them  There is pride and technique in each course  They time the courses perfectly

NgapNNErXajBp6Ro5I21Jg.review_text: Some people may say that Japanese food is bland in comparison to other Asian countries' food. Chinese food is heavy with exotic sauces, Korean food is spicy with fragrant flavors of garlic, soy and sesame, Thai food has different layers and intensity of spicy, sweet, and savory, etc. But actually, Japanese cuisine has delicate and subtle flavors and overpowering sauces or strong flavors are usually avoided so that you can appreciate the natural flavors of the food.   Kappa is just that. They hold true to drawing out and enhancing the natural flavors of the food you are eating. The entire meal was light , in small portions, and covered 7 courses. However, it was very filling. Presentation was very artful and I was amazed how talented the chef is at creating all of these delicate and subtle flavors in your mouth.   Course 1 - Shrimp Soup. A broth of shirmp stock, with snowpea, shrimp ball tempura and a touch of lemon zest. I found the lemon twist added a subtle taste in the background.  Course 2 - Fish tempura. 2 pieces of small fish, butterflied, lightly battered and deep fried tempura style. Just squeeze a bit of lemon and a bit of salt for a perfect balance.  Course 3 - Seared tuna with sweet miso sauce. This was raw tuna sashimi, lightly seared and topped with miso served with a shiso leaf.   Course 4 - Sashimi platter. 4 pieces of thickly sliced maguro (tuna), hamachi (yellowtail), tai (bream) and 1 more that I couldn't figure out, ,maybe seabass? They were all very fresh and delicious.   Course 5 - Platter of grilled shrimp, corn croquette, tonkatsu, chicken meatball, slowcooked tuna simmered in soysauce and spice, baked fish, duck with red miso, stingray, tamago egg, spicy fish roe wrapped in calamari. Everything was so good but I wasn't too crazy about the spicy fish eggs and calamari though. It was a bit salty. But everything else was impeccable.  Course 6 - Sushi course of grilled hamachi, unagi, and a baby scallop on the half shell with ume plum sauce. The unagi was fresh! Definetely not the type you find ready made in the frozen section of the asian grocer.  Course 7 - Dessert. Watermelon gelatin - A perfect intermezzo to cleanse the palate. Sliced papaya, pear, & persimmon. I usually hate persimmons but this one was very sweet. I couldn't believe it! Green tea cheese cake and mochi (rice dumpling with sweet bean jam) dusted with kinako (dried savory soy powder).  The mochi was so soft and delicious. A perfect ending.   Service is wonderful. The waitress is so humble and courteous and very attentive.   I think a second visit is in order.

cATChnWbNlodRD_Ua4mV0g.review_text: Kappa is an invitation to a delicious meal in a Japanese home! I loved all 7 delightful dishes cooked with precision and served with personal attention. I can't wait to go back!

jwAHZLtmPUV2JMLVykMaAw.review_text: One of the best Japanese meals I've every had. Also one of the most expensive. This place feels authentic with one table and a 10-person food bar. A couple has been running it for 20 yeras and the presentation is impeccable.  Make reservations. You pay for a prix fixe meal (they'll accommodate dietary restrictions). Each dish is simple with the freshest flavor. If you want to have an absolutely memorable dinner, take your date here.

Nm_oECledKFKPGjq6JjvIQ.review_text: After reading rave reviews about this place I took my parents here for my fathers birthday.  My dad is from Japan so I figured he would appreciate the place, and he did, but it definitely was not worth $450 for three people!    I've been to restaurants before that have costed this much, but they are far more gorgeous and the food is more rare and exquisite.  At Kappa, the 3 of us were sitting at a bar 2 feet away from the owners who were cooking our food.  The place is beyond tiny.  I felt like I could have gone across the street to nijiya and prepared the food at home and been more comfortable because my kitchen and dining space is bigger.  The owners do take a lot of time to prepare the food and present it, but its the same with any other restaurant, with exception to the price.  I just felt like I was really ripped off, omakase is $85, but if you decide to get anything else, watch out, one extra plate of normal quality sashimi could cost you another $85- $90.

WecuAsHBDZGj7Z6_sJcQAw.review_text: I went to Japan and back, but never had to leave the friendly confines of San Francisco. The location is tucked into a small, practically hidden space, the menu on the wall is printed in japanese, the friendly waitress/co-owner/wife of the chef/culinary navigator dresses in traditional attire, and the decor is zen friendly. They've been doing it for 22 years.  And then there is the food. Oh the food. I can't remember everything - we had the omakase and it kept coming and coming. It's truly a one of a kind experience so make reservations, take a seat and be prepared to take a culinary trip for your taste buds to Kyoto and back in 2 hours. 7-COURSE OMAKASE DINNER ($85) (1) Fishcake w/ Sea Urchin Soup: bit.ly/UGnkNh (2) Rare-cooked Tuna w/ Japanese Mustard & Scallion: bit.ly/T9MGUg (3)  Snow Crab w/ Cucumber in a Vinegar Broth: bit.ly/T1FQjx (4)  Variety Plate: Tsukune, Satsumaage, Blackskin Pork, Turnip, Black Cod, Tonkatsu, etc.: bit.ly/10nwvHE (5) Sashimi - Hamachi, Uni, Chu Toro & Amberjack: bit.ly/WiiPd1 (6) Nigiri - Baby Scallop, Unagi & Seared Toro: bit.ly/10nwQtZ (7) Mango Sorbet, Sweet Rice Cake, Melon, Persimmon &  Red Bean Jello: bit.ly/XxDU9H If you appreciate top-notch seasonal ingredients with subtle flavors and delicate textures, you will thoroughly enjoy every course at Kappa. The sashimi was ultra-silky and buttery while the slightly torched nigiri created a mouth-watering decadent mouth feel. The delicious simplicity of ripe, seasonal fruits was displayed in the fruit centered dessert closer course. Kappa is definitely a must for all foodies who can appreciate culinary greatness in its simplistic form. Going back to the Scott Disick doppelgänger, you know I couldn't leave without some parting words. I0ViOyrQqguZo-QSH9iDjQ.review_text: It's in a weird location. You don't expect a tiny space above Denny's (and next to Playground) to serve up an exquisite meal. But it does. oav3V6xd6osrh3uHY_2qxA.review_text: One night, my friend and I decided to finally try dinner at Kappa, a wonderful gem of a restaurant tucked away in a hidden corner of San Francisco's Japantown. Locating the restaurant for the first time was slightly challenging. We went up a flight of stairs from the J-town Denny's, peered skeptically into a Korean karaoke lounge, and finally found the entrance behind a sliding wooden door next to the lounge. The only indication of the restaurant's existence was a small sign with the words "Kappa" inscribed in neat hiragana.  Yet aside from the odd location, this was one of the best meals I've had outside of Japan. Once I stepped inside, I was instantly transported back to the small, intimate restaurants in Japan, where salarymen drink and eat in between hearty laughter after work hours. The restaurant can only fit about ten seats at the bar, so the dining experience allows you to converse with both the chef and his wife, who served customers while wearing a full kimono (which is very commendable since it's hard to even walk in kimono without looking like a penguin). I almost forgot that I was in the States.  As for the food, let me begin my review with some words of caution. Not everyone will appreciate the food at Kappa. The restaurant serves food in the koryori style, which is harder to find outside of Japan. Small, stand-alone dishes are presented with minimal garnish and seasoning, in an effort to highlight the original flavors of the ingredients. There is no standard menu, as the availability of items varies with the freshness of the ingredients. The result is a sensual, refined dining experience that allows you to enjoy the flavors, scents, and textures of some of the most traditional Japanese cuisine.  If you're looking for California rolls, contemporary fusion fare, gyoza, and teriyaki bento boxes, do not step foot into Kappa. And take your gaijin t-shirt with you. Kappa doesn't even serve sushi, although I'm sure the chef would do an amazing job if he wanted to.  For newbies, the best thing to order is probably the omakase pre-fixe menu. For $85 per person, the chef will select a variety of dishes to introduce you to koryori dining. My friend and I were fairly confident about what we wanted though, so we just ordered a la carte.  - Sashimi: Each slice was thick, juicy, melt-in-your-mouth perfection. Wasabi and shoyu were completely unnecessary. The uni was especially amazing. - Ankimo: Creamy and velvety, served with ponzu sauce.  - Hirame Usuzukuri: Thinly sliced halibut sashimi dipped in a mixture of shoyu, thinly sliced green onions, and spicy daikon. Great play on textures. - Grilled red snapper: Best dish of the meal. Reminiscent of hamachi kama, but the meat was thicker and sweeter. - Blackskin Pork: Thick and fried in batter without too much excess oil. - Anmitsu (agar jelly served with sweet bean paste)   With the limited seating, reservations are a must. The portions are small, so don't show up starving. And the prices can add up to a hefty total, but if you're a fan of traditional Japanese fare, it's well worth it to visit once in awhile. mkxCw6GsMZDu-44_aCQTHw.review_text: If you're reading this review because you made reservations and can't find the place, turn around and look up for the neon blue Playground sign.  Walk up those stairs and between the Bar and Playground is a dark wooden sliding door.  Proceed through the door.  This is like a speakeasy, you go in, it's quiet and it's clean.  The chaos of Japantown and the city disappears and you're in a little Japanese vacation.  We had the Koryori pre-fix meal with no meat.  It's interesting, the website and other reviews said there was no sushi, but we did actually get sushi (maybe b/c we didn't eat meat, it was in addition to the sashimi) -- I'm glad that happened because it was amazing!  There were parts that were the best I've ever had -- the scallops and yellow tail in particular.  The soup was excellent and all the presentation was beautiful.  The atmosphere was not relaxed, but in a way it made you focus on your food more.  It was delicate and I felt a lot more aware of my manners and etiquette.  I did pull out my cell phone to take pictures (I felt it to be a necessary faux pas fusion of modern and traditional culture!) but I will say the other diners in the restaurant kept having their phone going off -- it was on vibrate and while that generally wouldn't phase me, irritated me.  They are very attentive here and that may not be something everyone is interested in -- as soon as your glass is empty or food is finished you'll be served appropriately.  Some of the food was mediocre and forgettable, but even that was eaten with great appreciation.  There were some pieces that were amazing, but hard for me to justify going back for just a taste. oAlP03cHvPZrEgqWDdYAAw.review_text: WoOoOoOoOw!!!! this place is top-notch!   everything from the food and service.  yes theres a lady (Rumiko) that walks around in a beautiful kimono. yes this place is hard to find. yes the portions are small.  and yes $85 is rather steep per person. but i thought i got my money's worth! let me tell you, the food here is outstanding! i dont know why some of  these hating ass  motherfuckers didnt appreciate the food as much as i did.  this has to be one of the best japanese dining experiences i've ever had. and one of my new favorite japanese restaurants. if everyday were a special occasion (and if i had a billion dollars), you would definately find me here!  maybe i should just kidnap the chef. anyone wanna help? sorry rumiko san he's coming with us! jk.  no seriously. its that good.  the omakase (pre-fixed menu) consisted of 7 courses. if its your first time coming to this restaurant, i would highly suggest ordering this. each and every dish was beautifully presented and VERY delicious. oh and everything tasted FRESH! i made sure i savored every morsel of food.   my favorite dish was the kani su (crab sunomono). best sunomono ever! for $20 a pop, it better be! they use real crab meat and you get a good amount of it!  i also liked the kani nigiri. omg, i would choke a bitch for another one of those!! that shit was hella good! i also have to mention they have the best wasabi i've ever tasted. they use the fresh shit.  not the one you get in a tube or the powder shit. but the fresh shit.  you can tell by the texture and grittyness that it was freshly grated.  and they get it from seattle. how do i know? cuz i asked the chef and he showed me the actual root!  EVERYTHING was very good. and the service was also great.  it did not disappointment me one bit.  FYI, they DO NOT SERVE SUSHI!! so get the fuck out of here with your i-love-big-ass-sushi-that-cant-even-fit-in-my-­mouth bullshit!  no seriously.  go somewhere else if you're looking for quantity instead of quality. if they DID serve sushi here, i think the chef would do a stupendous job! cuz that kani nigiri and sashimi was incredible! but do come here if you want to experience fine and traditional japanese dining. oh and learn to read hiragana. the sign in front is written in japanese. no english whatsoever!  good luck finding it. lucky for me i know how to read it. dont forget to make a reservation! oh and prepare to drop $100 per person.

cEytkA4KL08f46JOjkbcVw.review_text: Walking into this hidden gem is like walking into a Japanese speakeasy. But instead of booze and debauchery there's serenity and a transcendental food experience. 35CVnpI59bKN1rlCBgaSxQ.review_text: I ate here years ago after reading an excellent review of it by Patricia Unterman, which I can't find any where, even on the Examiner's website.  It was probably lost in the course of the various regime changes at the paper.  However, there are 2 more current reviews in the Chonicle, which reinforce my opinion of the place.   sfgate.com/cgi-bin/artic… sfgate.com/cgi-bin/artic… It was difficult to find, but well worth the effort and part of the charm of the restaurant is it's exclusiveness -- a secret place that only you and a few other people know about.  It's also not cheap, but worth every penny. Q3QX0qCcaubqJPUwf4mY1w.review_text: My wife and I went to Kappa the other night for our 25th anniversary celebration.  This was our third visit to Kappa, and I really wanted something extraordinary and special for our 25th, so I knew it had to be dinner here.    As usual, we were amazed at the food and the overall dining experience.  Kappa is unique in many ways...  it's tucked away behind a practically hidden sliding door.  If you look carefully, you'll see "Kappa" in small letters adjacent to the door.  It's tiny, I think we counted a total of 14 seats capacity.  But a tiny, hidden venue like this is inline with the tradition of "Koryori" style Japanese cuisine, which emphasizes homemade, small plates.    Run by a husband and wife team, you  are treated as if honored guests in their home.  They are extremely cordial and attentive from the moment you walk in, offering hot towels.  If you order the "prix fixe" dinner, be prepared for an awesome treat.   The small plates change seasonally and according to what they are getting freshest from the market, but we had:   #1  grilled, sauteed japanese eggplant and scallions.   (tender, bursting with flavor) #2  rice vinegar cucumbers and fresh dungeness crab  (awesome, fresh, tart, delectable) #3  main course, with variety of treats (chicken meatball, prawn, corn fritter, duck medallion, pork katsu, roe wrapped in calamari, asparagus, marinated halibut (all incredible delicacies, one or two bites each) #4  sashimi plate  (generous portions of absolutely fresh yellowtail, tuna, amberjack, halibut) #5  grilled fish plate (grilled yellowtail, baby scallop and eel.  I love unagi sushi, but this was by far the best I've ever sampled - fresh, plump, tender, perfectly grilled) #6  dessert plate (red bean gel, cherry, mango) #7  fresh sorbet (melon, homemade.  Again, out of this world - best I've ever had).  We enjoyed all this along with a fine, dry sake and green tea afterwards.   Sounds like alot, but they portion it and pace it perfectly so you do not feel grossly stuffed at all.  Just utterly and completely satisfied.   This is  a rare dining experience, for special occasions, and needless to say - expensive.  Plan for about $120 per person if having the prix fixe along with liquor.  A little less ($80 -100 per person) if ordering a la carte, which is also a great choice.  THere are plenty of restaurants we've eaten that I'd have to say are overpriced, but this is definitely NOT ONE OF THEM.  This is fine dining at it's best.

ex9Vcw4RSggat0UHwlOrvg.review_text: Kappa is a place that's still around not because the food is good or memorable, but because there are a ton of Americans who have no idea what real Japanese food should taste like, but go to Japantown in SF looking for something "authentic" and decide that this place is worth the splurge.

6BPWg3w-B0IphHnePrYt-w.review_text: Summary: if you have eaten very good Japanese tapas restaurants (izakaya) such as Tanto, Gochi, and Saizo, and are ready to experience the extra sophistication in taste, the food is worth the extra spending.  Now here's the whole story.  My mother, since moving to the small town in Texas, has missed quality Japanese food.  She told me she would treat me as my birthday present, so as I have not tried this place, I offered this place to her, somewhat worried that she might say no given the expected splurge.  She said yes, after not being to reserve a table at Kaygetsu.  It's not easy to find the entrance to this place.  Basically, go up the step right at the front of Denny's in SF Japan town, open the double door that says "club ??? (I forgot the name)," and find the lantern right away.  Right to that is the entrance to Kappa.  If you turn left, you'll go into the club.  Once inside, you'll notice that the place is definitely small.  It actually reminds me of a quality Japanese restaurant in the middle of Tokyo, even though the food served is Kyoto style (slightly sweeter than Tokyo style, with more frequency of seaweed broth being used).    The waitress was an attentive Japanese woman who makes conversation to customers for hospitality.  The male chef likewise was attentive and quick on customer's orders.  Because this place only serves 13 people, though, they could do that.    The menu only has 30 or so dishes, but boy, were these dishes sophisticated or not.  Fried beefsteak leaves with miso paste inside was a nice way to ignite appetite for further dishes and sake.  Simmered Tanba (a region in Kyoto(?) that is traditionally famous for beans) black bean was sweet, but also delicate.  My kid sister really liked sheared tuna with grated yam on top.  Indeed, inside there was a small amount of broth and freshly-grated wasabi.  Mixing them with soy sauce made this dish wonderful.  Tuna itself was also great.  They also had senmai-zuke, which is pickled turnip with seaweed.  They seem to make their own pickles, and the quality was mouthwatering.  Most American probably would not care for pickles, but if you like other kinds of pickles (kim chee, sauerkraut), you should try this kind of home-made Japanese pickles as well.  Their bite-size pork cutlet was well cooked, but with a lot of flavor.  The bread batter might have to do with it, but the quality of pork (kuro buta = black pork in Japan) probably plays the role too.  Stewed green was easy to eat, but still full of flavor thanks to deep-fried been curd and a hint of red pepper.  Grilled minced chicken and Shiitake mushroom were a little crunchy on outside, and soft and flavorful on inside.  It's not easy to grill like this, trust me.  Their ochazuke was delicate and light.  I was able to finish even though I was pretty full right before that.    Yes, the bill was pretty steep.  But my mother definitely enjoyed the dish, understanding the worthiness of the food she appreciated so much.  I have to agree with her.  On the side story, my mother was aggressive enough to ask the waitress to see if they could use her hand-made glass plate for the restaurant.  While the waitress declined the offer after asking the chef, she was gracious enough to ask him in the first place.  That shows the attentiveness this restaurant gives to customers.

ULG28-Vu8seliYuaHSeNag.review_text: Upon coming into Kappa, we felt immediately as if we had been transported back to Japan (which we have been to a handful of times). Japan is full of these tiny restaurants that only seat a handful of people. Everyone at the bar, including us, had the omakase and it did not disappoint. The chef's wife was the sole server and very efficient and friendly. She explained what each course was and answered any questions we had. The courses were creative, beautiful, and tasteful. We went from course to course efficiently, yet didn't feel as if we were being rushed - dinner still took about an hour and a half. There was plenty of food and we left feeling stuffed. There was a good amount of sushi but be prepared to try other (delicious) things as well. As we are from the East Coast, where omakases from fancy restaurants can be much more expensive, we felt that the price here, though not cheap, was very reasonable for the quality of food and the service. What a special experience! I have recommended it to all of my friends in the San Francisco area for a nice date night for special occasion.

4qsVIa8wP0EDk86VogIs1Q.review_text: However, a stunning dinner last evening at Kappa is where I'll start... A farewell to a good friend was a great reason to return here...  An opening course comprised of a gelatinous goo comprised of okra and clarified fish stock on top fresh scallops, topped with large roe. A clean, bright starter...  Kinpira-gobo. This is basically simmered burdock root which had a dressing of mostly sesame oil and seeds with a little red pepper flakes.  A series of small bites; reading from left to right starting from the top-left: cold, seared marinated duck breast (tender and rich), squid rolled around fish roe, grilled meatball. Second row: sea snail, "sushi" of egg yolk wrapped with shrimp and cucumber, ankimo. Third row: tamagoyaki, smoked scallop, anago sushi. I love this presentation and all the various bites that are presented.  Assorted sashimi: Very decent hamachi (yellowtail), halibut (very good, very tender), 2 pieces of maguro, and mirugai (giant clam). Also, real wasabi, which was sweet and not too hot.  The fried bits; a corn fritter, a crab puff, cold seared toro, and black-skin pork, tonkatsu-style. The corn fritter was amazing - literally bursting squirts of freshness. The pork was tender and rich and the toro literally melted in the mouth.  Nearing the finish, served in a martini glass was a concoction of pureed fava beans in which was set a single perfect bite of shrimp. Topping all of it was jellied fish broth. I'm not sure I have ever experienced the single essence of fava beans so delicately prepared.  The sweet bites: Along with a selection of fresh melon and mango, are two house-made preparations - the one on the left is filled with red bean paste and topped with soy powder, kinako, and the one on the right molded with white bean and chestnut, a kuri wagashi.  A word on service - this is a husband-and-wife establishment and with only ten seats, reservations are required as all the service is done by the Mrs. The plates and utensils used are delicate, expensive, and quite beautiful. The entire meal is a treat.

AdReAFj-qXPdZ-Ovx0LmiA.review_text: Episode 6 of Minami-ke Okaeri (Japanese Anime), at about the 21:55 mark. Apparently one of the characters made a big deal about "Matsutake Mushrooms".  Wondering whats the big deal with these mushrooms, I immediately paused the episode and went on Google.  Found out this mushroom is rare and hard to harvest; piquing my interest, I then hopped on Yelp and searched for "Matsutake Mushrooms" to see where I can eat such rare mushrooms.  The results led me to this tiny traditional Japanese restaurant called Kappa. Kappa is located next to Playground, a Korean restaurant/bar.  Though I had been to Playground before, i never imagined such a restaurant existed here.  First time I came here I wanted the Omakse, but that requires 1 day advance notice so I decided to pick individual items out of their menu instead.  Obviously I got the grilled Matsutake Mushrooms static2.px.yelp.com/bpho… The Hamachi Neck yelp.com/biz_photos/jI7h… and got some Ankimo, combination sashimi, chicken meatballs and the crab sunomono.  They were all very good, though I wanted to try the Omakase.  I decided to come a second time and called in advance so they can prepare my Omakase. The spicy roe wrapped with squid was outstanding.  Other items on the plate consist of tamago, duck breast, ankimo, smoked salmon, hamachi, red bean paste and the giant shrimp.   Course 5 was a combination of fresh sashimi yelp.com/biz_photos/jI7h… Course 6 includes a pork katsu, fried hamachi, unagi and a piece of pumpkin. yelp.com/biz_photos/jI7h… Finally this brings us to the deserts.  The mizuyokan is a kind of traditional japanese red bean gelatin accompanied with a green tea mochi and vanila ice cream topped with grean tea powder.   yelp.com/biz_photos/jI7h… We finished up with a plate of fresh fruits. Everything in this little restaurant is delicious.  The wife that works here is very nice.  Both times we went she was wearing a kimono or a yukata. (i cant tell the difference)  She would talk to us while we ate and explain to us what each item is called and how its prepared.  The tea here is delicious as well.  At $85 a person for the omakase, for all the different types of food you get, Its definitely worth the money!

XrRwbRbPMnC--kUXMtkTSw.review_text: Forget Gary Danko, forget Michael Mina. Neither of those restaurants have impressed me or my foodie friends. To date, the only "high end" restaurant that I would recommend unequivocally was Myth... but Myth was never special occasion high end, and now its changed owners.  And then we met Kappa.  Certainly, Kappa doesn't seem like a schmancy place: it's upstairs from the Japantown Denny's, with an unmarked door, and seating for no more than 10. But the food, the service... its heavenly. Plus, one of the things that I was not impressed by Gary Danko was that the food they served was so generic. It was damn good, for sure, but I can get good foie gras just about anywhere these days.  Kappa is like no other restaurant - Japanese or otherwise - that I've been to. John and I went last Tuesday for his 30th birthday, and it was a wonderful experience. We ordered the omakase so we didn't have to think about what to order, and what paired well with what. We were the only two customers in the place until the last 30 mins, so Rumiko (the owner) fussed about us. Everything was superbly presented. All we had to do was to order a sake, and enjoy the food.  Even though each taste was just a morsel, by the end of the night, even Mr. Hollow Leg John was stuffed. Besides, the flavors were so rich and different that we were able to savor each bite.  It will be hard to top something like Kappa. But that's ok, that's why we have special occasions only occasionally.

MjlNTynslY_aLDTfGODuIg.review_text: This place is the only place of its kind in the city, and perhaps anywhere in the vicinity. I will try to explain why that is, but it will be extremely difficult. 65uUyG9yuF0rdMh0z7ajaA.review_text: Absolutely, positively fantastic. 4 of us made a reservation for the omakase (pre-fixe) meal this past Saturday.  When we walked in and were greeted by the hostess (in full kimono), and seated at 4 seats in the middle of the bar - the only seats in the restaurant with table settings.  Turns out, we were the only customers that evening. We asked the hostess to select a sake for us to start with, and 2 hours of foodie bliss began. The general format was that for each course, the chef (her husband) would come out front and prepare the course, then would return to the back while she served it and we ate.  It wasn't clear if he wasn't particularly chatty, or just didn't speak as much English.  Know that part of eating here is talking to and interacting with the hostess - she not only explains what each course is, but is also interested in chatting with you during the meal, learning about her customers and making it an interactive dining experience.  If you're looking for a place to huddle over a table in the corner and just stare into your date's eyes, this isn't the place for you. ;) Her English was quite good, but many times I was glad I could speak some Japanese - I think it helped break the ice, and made the experience more fun for everyone.  So what did we have? 1 - chicken meatball with a slice of shiitake mushroom and a couple of other things in a light but very flavorful soup broth. 2 - Japanese eggplant in ponzu sauce with bonito flakes 3 - Dungeness crab meat, and lightly pickled cucumber with sesame seeds 4 - a large square plate with a number of wonderful bite-sized items, all arranged around a huge raw prawn, including: duck breast, monkfish liver, smoked-salmon nigiri, lotus root slice, tako-yaki, burdock root wrapped in sea eel, sweet red beans, tamago, cooked hamachi, crispy tofu, and spicy cod roe wrapped in squid(?).  beautiful presentation. 5 - sashimi plate with maguro, hamachi, kanpachi, and hirame I believe 6 - a plate of hot food bites - fried fish cake with fresh ginger, panko fried scallop, fresh corn fritter, and the most amazing melt-in-your-mouth unagi I've ever had 7 - first dessert - slices of incredibly fresh, sweet fruit: mango, peach, and melon, accompanied by a homemade mochi-like gooey sweet rice ball with red bean paste 8 - second dessert - vanilla ice cream with black sugar sauce and soy bean powder  The desserts were accompanied by a fantastic green tea.  Every single thing we ate was fantastic.  Rich, subtle, simple, complex, balanced... pick a superlative adjective, and it would apply. About halfway through our meal we noticed that the slabs of fish in the display case at the bar weren't being returned (as they usually would at a sushi restaurant) after they were taken out for each course, and we realized that we were eating all of them.  All of the fish had been purchased specifically for our meal, which explained its fantastic freshness and quality.  We also ended up having 5 different sake over the course of the evening (which racks up quite a bill, but was entirely worth it!).  The hostess is very knowledgeable about all of their sake, and is happy to recommend ones appropriate to the meal at hand.  Everything we drank paired magnificently with the food; it was easy to tell these items were meant to go together.  Our favorites were the Naraman (Jyunmai), which was dry but very complex, fruity, and flavorful, and the Kagatobi (Ginjo), which was fascinatingly similar to a hard, mineral water in flavor, while very clearly not being water.  2 hours after we'd arrived, our luxurious meal had come to an end.  It had been the perfect amount of food - we were all happily full, none of us too full, none remotely hungry.  A truly spectacular meal, and an incredibly unique, very intimately Japanese experience that made me nostalgic for my time in Japan.  It's not remotely cheap (especially when you drink as much as we did!), but it's completely worth it.
